item.title: 4 Life-Saving Tips for New Shooters
item.creator: JimWilson
item.content_encoded: Personal-defense training and gear has become a big business. There is so much out there in terms of training, guns, ammo and equipment that the new shooter can easily be confused as to what is available and what is really needed. It is almost like wandering around in a maze. At best the process can cost a person a lot of time, money, and frustration. At the worst, it can get that person killed. What follows are four easy-to-remember tips that will keep the new shooter headed in the right direction. 1. Get Professional Training Personal protection doesn't begin with buying a defensive handgun, it starts with getting proper training. A professional training school does not teach a person to be a great action-shooting competitor, it teaches the student to fight. Consequently, a professional training school is run, or designed, by people who have actually fought. I know of only a handful of top-notch instructors who have not been in a gunfight and they teach at a school that was designed by a fighter. An instructor with experience truly knows what the student will be faced with in a deadly encounter. He didn't read about it somewhere; he lived it. It is also wise to avoid defensive schools that make a big deal about all of their instructors having military background and experience. With all due respect to those who have actually served, the task of the soldier is different from that of the armed citizen. The soldier's task is to go to, or face, the sound of gunfire and he may have to fire numerous rounds to accomplish this task. The armed citizen should be taught to avoid conflict if at all possible and will generally only fire a few rounds when avoidance is not an option. Good defensive training schools are expensive, so it important to make sure that money is spent wisely. A good school has a good reputation and is happy to give references. It is also quite specific about all of the costs and requirements involved in signing up for a class. Before committing, the potential student should talk to as many people who have received training at this school as possible. Check it out thoroughly, like it was some guy wanting to marry your daughter. I have attended three training schools that I can recommend without reservation. They are the Gunsite Academy, the Sig Academy and Thunder Ranch. They meet all of the criteria that I have previously mentioned and are staffed by excellent teachers who do everything in their power to help the student succeed. Don't go cheap on your training. 2. Buy the Best Defensive Gear You Can Possibly Afford Good defensive handguns and equipment are not cheap. However, the good news is that a good quality handgun will last for generations. The gun that I rely on most is a .45 Colt automatic that is over 40 years old. A good defensive handgun is a lifetime investment, so why not get a good one? Remember that I said that getting good training was the place to start in becoming a defensive shooter? One might ask how that is done if you don't already own a suitable defensive handgun. It's quite simple, actually. In the course of signing up for your class, you tell them that you are a new shooter, answer any other questions they might ask and arrange to rent a school gun that the instructor feels is suited to you. While at the school it is a good idea to observe the guns and gear that the instructors are using. Don't be afraid to ask questions and don't be afraid to ask to try other guns that might be available. Two common pitfalls in the quest for a defensive handgun are asking policemen and gun-store staff for advice. Sadly, most policemen just don't know much about defensive handguns except for the one that their department says they have to carry. Sales staff, on the other hand, rarely have any actual gunfighting experience and are prone to simply promote whatever guns the boss told them needed to be sold. The same goes for holsters, ammunition and other defensive accessories. You are going to be paying good money for that defensive school. You are far better off letting that professional instructor guide you in finding the right defensive handgun, one that will actually suit you and meet your needs. 3. Internet Gun Forums are a Waste of Time Well, that is not exactly true. Internet gun forums can be very entertaining, often better than watching sit-coms on TV. It's just that they are a wasteland when one is seeking good information. New defensive shooters have a ton of questions. And then, after completing a defensive handgun class, they have tons and tons of questions. Reading the blather of some nameless, faceless Internet gun “expert” is not the place to get good answers to those questions. Remember that professional defensive school that you spent so much money on? That is the place to go for information and answers. Once you have completed a class at one of these schools, you become a part of its extended family. You will generally come away with your instructor's e-mail address and maybe even his/her phone number. That is the best place to go for answers to your questions about personal defense. Good instructors are happy to be of service and, besides, these contacts will often lead to additional training. The exception to contacting your defensive instructor is when you are seeking legal advice. The best source for that information is a local attorney who specializes in criminal defense. Just as a word of caution, the legal advice you can get from the Internet gun forums is worse than their personal-defense advice. 4. Practice The ability to shoot quickly and accurately, as with all other martial arts, is a rapidly diminishing skill. All of the good stuff that you learned at the defensive training school is wasted and lost if you don't practice it fairly regularly. The good news is that your defensive school knows this and will be happy to supply you with practice routines that you can take home and use to keep your skills honed. It is also a good idea to book additional training as often as you can. I try to take at least one class per year and would take more if my budget could afford it. There you have it, four tips that will get your personal defense plan started in the right direction from the very beginning. If there were a fifth tip it would be, “Don't Go Cheap.” Wannabe instructors are a waste of good money. Sorry guns are a waste of good money. Ditto for sorry ammo and gear. Good personal-defense training and gear costs money. Only you can decide what your life is worth.
item.excerpt_encoded: Personal-defense training is big business. So how do you know what you really need? If you are new to shooting, follow these four easy-to-remember tips to keep you on track.

comment.comment_content: Thanks for the heads up good advice <!--mobile-->
So, after reading section 1, it sounds like you are saying its a waste of time to attend a NRA basic pistol class?

So basically, you are saying that those people who can't afford the travel costs and tuition for one of three elitist schools, can't afford to drop several hundred to a grand or better on a gun, and a few hundred more on gear, shouldn't consider a firearm for personal defense. Since when did the exercise of our 2nd Amendment rights become a viable option only for the wealthy?<!--mobile-->

John Burton...
Perhaps you should re-read the article and then reconsider your question.
NRA Basic Pistol is NOT a defensive curriculum. It is exactly what it's name implies: a BASIC primer course.
It is NOT a defensive course. Nor are those whose SOLE certification is in this discipline qualified to teach defensive or 'tactical' curriculums.
NRA Basic Pistol is an excellent introductory course and is highly recommended for new or novice shooters. It teaches the BASICS that are necessary and critical to a new or novice shooter advancing beyond the introductory stage. <!--mobile-->

I wish 'mindset' was listed in here. These are all fine points, don't get me wrong. Especially the bit about training. But it's been my experience that these training courses focus more on the techniques, form, and reaction to given situations vs. actually being mentally prepared at all times. Good link, but if I had the chance to add a tip it would be to develop a mindset of awareness. After all, the best defense to any would be crime is to be ready for it, or possibly avoid it all together. Lt. Col. Dave Grossman has some books and DVD's that cover this concept pretty well. I'd encourage folks to get one and read it.

The author is not saying that you can carry a gun only if you have travelled hundreds of miles to Gunsite and bought a Wilson Combat with a custom-made holster and have a 30-year retired LEO who served on the LAPD SIS as your instructor. He is outlining the ideal path for the beginner to follow--namely, to find instruction first, then buy gun. Almost everyone who is new to guns starts at the gun store. I would add the advice that even the best of gun books, though generally more correct in their advice than the Internet, still only give an overview. To paraphrase Mr. Miyagi from The Karate Kid: 'No can learn karate from book.' That is the theory; the application is much harder. I have talked to lots of instructors at gun shows and various gun stores--everyone seems to offer freelance lessons--and it is impossible for a newbie with no prior connection to distinguish between them. Everyone's a retired cop or combat veteran. Also, many of the classes are not suited to the actual handguns that people carry--what good is it to take a class with your Glock 19 when you actually carry a P238? But in any case, we have to start with sound principles of gun ownership, and this article is well taken.

Jeff - I think the gun you buy, the classes you take, the training you go through is all relative to your income. I know people with Ed Brown 1911's. I have a XDm. Some people go to Gunsite, I'm going to a local trainer for $200 and 8 hours of instruction. That's kind of the beauty of the 2nd Amendment. Nobody is locked out of it based on cost.

I disagree with one of the authors points. You can buy a cheap, very good gun they are out there. Just look at something like the makarov $200 cold war surplus gun. Easy to use, will last forever, very accurate. There are many other guns often used that you can come across that will suit your needs great without breaking the bank.
If Keith Hanson.....is the Kieth I know. In SWF. He is a man that would known. One of the best in the US! Keith is an awesome instructor.<!--mobile-->

Buying the most expensive handgun and ammo in the world does not remedy unfamiliarity with shooting skills, as in keeping a steady aim, target recognition, and the most important thing--not succumbing to adrenalin.

Those 'in the know' will read that article and nod their heads in agreements.
Those who don't get the article's points now, probably never will.
Jeff, + 1000 I agree, quality training is a great thing. However, not having it should not be a prerequisite to a right. I wonder how many defensive gun uses were 'trained'.

Life-Saving Tips has nothing to do with expensive gears and professional training.
Life Saving Tips are:
Handgun safety, Firearm safety 1. Safety 2. Safety 3. Safety 4. Safety
And you can learn ALOT over internet forum. There are more than enough useful information all over the internet forums. Good or Bad but it is not all waste of the time.

As the owner/administrator of a gun forum, I feel the need to defend myself and my community after reading number 3. Sure, there are a lot of bad opinions online or anywhere you go to ask people questions. The key is how much weight you give to the answers that you receive. If a new gun owner comes to our forum, there are a lot of people who are willing to help, and in many cases, the 'helpers' are very clear to point out that their answer may not be the most correct, nor is it to be taken as legal advice. That said, I believe that any insight that you can get from others' experiences, even if sometimes a little off the mark, is worth reading, considering and applying to your own situation as necessary [(]or ignoring all together, in some cases[)].

I have been through 5 Security and LE schools in the USAF, and two civilian schools for large armed security companies. Some of th7e best information on staying alive during shooting situations I learned from police officers in the CWP classes[(]8hr.[)] required by my home state. I hope soon to go back to advanced classes these guys might have.

Saying 'Internet Gun Forums are a Waste of Time ' immediately drops your credibility. Front Sight has a very good forum that includes information from some of the best. Blanket statements are not helpful.

I'd add LEO to the list of qualities that do NOT necessarily qualify someone to teach. The LEO job is much different than that of CHL. Being in a gun fight is an example of failure in tactics or decision making. So they lived. Were they lucky or good? There are a few instructors that survived multiple encounters but I think there are many others that avoided a fight and can teach you to do likewise. I've been to multiple schools and I learned from each one. [(]Some I learned what NOT to do. :[)] [)]

Prepare to flame me. The article was titled as tips for new shooters. But then goes on to name advanced instruction. I have been shooting and hunting for 52 years. I practice regularly and can hit what I aim at. I recently purchased my first AR, and thought maybe I should get some training. Let me list the requirements, one or three point sling [(] mines two[)]. Minimum 1500 rounds of ammo, minimum 10 30 round mags, battle vest or 10 mag pouches. As a retired senior citizen I don't plan on being deployed anytime soon, so this was just too much. So I went on the internet, filtered information, set up my rifle with a red dot and buis and sighted it in. Been having a great time shooting it ever since. God bless those that want advanced training for whatever reason, but testosterone filled youngsters are just not for me. I just like practicing my aim and mastering my weapons. OK. Flame on.

I like Jeff Cooper's four life saving tips better: 1.All guns are always loaded. 2.Never let the muzzle cover anything you are not willing to destroy. 3.Keep your finger off the trigger until your sights are on the target. 4.Be sure of your target and what is beyond it.

Thanks for a great, focused article. My NRA Handgun Instructor's Cert. did in no way qualify me to provide self-defense methods. My SD training came from a professional in California, who was trained at all of those SD facilities you mentioned. I agree with all four points, however the forums are entertaining and provide hands-on opinions about firearms I have not experience with. Great advice, especially on quality of instruction and practice.

As said by VGOF.net, I have to disagree with your advice about the information provided on internet forums, at least on many of them. The forum posters may or may not be experts or provide reliable information on many topics or applicable to a specific geographic area. But they can provide valuable guidance and information on a mired of topics or specific problems a shooter, new or old, may encounter. Yes, a person must make a personal evaluation of the value of the information and in many cases sort out the opinions from the facts, but finding out what others use or have experienced can contribute greatly to the learning experience.

I especially like point #3. I am amazed how many folks attain 'Expert Mall Ninja' status by simply watching YouTube videos. Watching videos & reading blogs should not be considered to be absolute training. I only wished that more people had such an accurate approach to training & defensive abilities as what you have written about in this article.
Great job!! Hope to see more from you in the future.

I hope that what most get from reading this is that the gun store is not the first place to go when you want to buy one or feel the need to. There are many statistics that highlight those who have purchased guns and are untrained run into issues during the real world scenarios. Forums are a good source of information if you use it properly. Opinions on handgun makes and models, preferences, and experience can help make a difference.
When I started out, I looked at forums and asked questions. One of the most important was to look and try before I buy. I'm one that feels anyone purchasing a firearm should have training as a prerequisite. Yes there are some who will yell at me for this but think of the guy in all the movies shooting himself or others, what's worst is this happens in real life.
No back to the article. I feel that to truly be able to handle the stress, adrenaline and pressures of a real life scenario is to be put in one and train for it. Unless you're confronted with it, how can you be sure at 3am, in the dark, you will be able to properly address the scenario safely [(]no Pistorius[)] or even be able to pull the trigger saving your family's life.
I don't believe you need to buy the most expensive high end gear. What is important is something that is reliable, has a proven track record and fits you. By fits you I don't mean the blinged out firearm or the desert eagle, rather what fits your hand properly, you're comfortable with and allows you to be in control of the firearm.
I mentioned forums before so I'll only say, there are those on forums who can provide valuable advice. You can get opinions from those who have used the firearm you are looking to purchase. Useful links to accessories [(]holsters, etc.[)].
And last is practice. First point to this is to learn proper firearm stances and shooting procedures. Start with the basics, read and learn before you fire the gun [(]yes we're all eager to use the new firearm[)]. Keep going to the range and hone your skills. Get professional training if needed and don't be afraid to do that.
And finally, taking a lesson I was once taught, if you don't fear it, you lose respect for it. Keep in mind that this is not a toy, it's a tool and like any tool that is misused, abused or not respected bad things can happen to you, the tool or others.
Be safe out there!

@Jeff What he is saying is to buy the best quality you can afford, be it a weapon, training, a holster or other accessories. If you can't afford Gun sight, take a defensive course from a local instructor. The author is giving his opinion on a reasonable course of action for any one needing this info. Someone who carries is accepting a level of responsibility well above just about anything I can think of, responsibility to themselves, their loved ones AND the general public and should take all action that they can to learn and be a responsible carrier.<!--mobile-->
I say never miss an opportunity to learn no matter where the info cones from.<!--mobile-->

Great article and as usual, some trolls just don't get it. Nobody's saying you can't buy and inexpensive gun, or get training from someone else. However, the BEST route to learning defensive handgunning is to get trained by real, qualified TEACHERS, not some wannabe's or super-ninja. Then go out and buy the best gun you can afford, along with a lot of practice ammo, and the time to use it, as well as participate in DRY practice.

I agree. I attended Thunder Ranch Defensive Handgun last fall. I learned more in three days about how to stay alive in a gunfight than I had in a lifetime of reading articles and surfing the forums. Bottom line; you don't know what you don't know. Can't wait to go back!<!--mobile-->

'There is so much out there in terms of training, guns, ammo and equipment that the new shooter can easily be confused as to what is available and what is really needed. It is almost like wandering around in a maze. At best the process can cost a person a lot of time, money, and frustration. At the worst, it can get that person killed.' Training, practice, and how deep your pockets are aside, your readers expect that the collective wisdom of the American Rifleman staff could at least come up with the minimum calibers and the preferred calibers to be recommended for a self-defense handgun. Then comes the practice for sure and the training hopefully, but at least he/she has a chance of defending their life now. With the words '...get that person killed' fresh in your mind, would you say that a healthy and able person should buy a .22 or a .380 to keep from getting killed? The FBI used to believe in the .38 Special and 9mm but now believes in the .40. The Law Enforcement Community used to believe in the .38 Special and 9mm but now believes in the .40. The military has had a terrible track record with the 9mm using FMJ bullets but the FBI and Law Enforcement used HPs and they still ditched it. It's time to establish some realistic standards so that our members don't get brainwashed into buying mouse guns and getting themselves killed. Remember I said healthy and able people, not infirmed or otherwise incapable of using a minimum or preferred caliber; they get to shoot anything that goes bang. Based on what we know today, it would seem that we could name the .38 Special and 9mm as the minimum calibers endorsed for self-defense and the .40 and .45 as the preferred autos and the .357 and up as the preferred revolvers. Remember that the gold standard for a great self-defense caliber is penetration and very large holes; that separates the minimum calibers from the preferred calibers. What would the American Rifleman recommend if the bad guy was in the dark and/or moving, both circumstances that could void the 'well-placed-shot with a mouse gun' theory. Should your readers be warned that they should prepare for the worst case scenario: a kind-of-well-placed-shot, a really big bad guy wearing lots of protective clothing, and high on drugs? Please tell your readers that bad guys can shoot back until they are on the ground and that trading shots with your mouse gun is going to get you killed. Don't tell us about small mouse guns that fit in our pocket. Do your duty and help keep us alive by recommending what we should have in our hand, no matter what.

All of the technical training in the world will do no good if a person doesn't have the right mind set. I am retired Army and I have had to wirk with my wife for years to get her head right to use a weapon in situations that dictated deadly force. It's as much as between the ears as it is technical. <!--mobile-->

Please do not disregard any firearm due to caliber, other than a common reliability issue amongst the smaller calibers. The 'its just a 22'mentality is a dangerous , and often deadly one! Remember, a large caliber leaves the body, you have to go in and get a small cal. .. The important thing is that you feel comfortable and above all else, can efficiently operate you firearm. <!--mobile-->
I wonder how many people have easy access to a firing range in order to take Step 4. I certainly don't and I live in southern Michigan.

Horrible article. I guess LEO's wouldn't know much about defensive weapons because oh wait most LEO's carry small defensive weapons for just that reason while off duty. They also train with them. Also why spend $1000 on a Colt when a Glock is $450. <!--mobile-->

A larger calipers is not as important as is proficiency. If the user will shoot a smaller caliber with a higher magazine capacity more often and feel more comfortable with that then that's what they should carry. The fact is no handgun caliper will knock a person down. There is no recommended minimum caliper. If a woman can fire off more rounds more accurately with a smaller caliper then that's what she should be shooting. Two hollow point .22 lr. In the chest can be just as deadly as one .40.<!--mobile-->

Look 9mm is good for practice but you want a caliber that will stop a target in his tracks. Go for nothing less than .40. I have tons of friends ask me if .380 is enough, and I tell them only for a backup. Personally I carry a .40 as primary and a 9mm makarov as backup<!--mobile-->

pricey 45acp 1911 for beginner?? about the worst you can do as a beginner. i went that way and it was so wrong. its better to get a 22 or 9mm gun. learn basic safety, basic marksmanship. then attend trainings and competitions. <!--mobile-->

I have DECADES of real world hands on experience. When I go into these online forums and see these mall ninjas posting ridiculous advice to people,I have no choice but jump in and and warn them off before they actually believe the so called advice. But then I become the so called 'mall Ninja'. It is sad what these individuals believe is safe and sound advice. I have seen advice being given that would result in horrendous effects. one of the most recent was 'Only wound your assailant, they will stop and run and that way their family wont sue you' The worst part was this individual claimed to be a 'concealed carry instructor'...
This is very good info. Thanks!
Looks like the Comments section here is looking more and more like a gun forum thread.<!--mobile-->

Good article. However, the article makes it sound like these tips are not flexible. Buying the best gear is very important. My advice is to shop around at different types of stores and ask questions. If you go to a 'box store' they probably are just selling what they are told. However, if you go to a locally owned shop it is usually a different story. I work in a local gun shop and everyone there is always willing to give advise and answer questions without trying to sell you to most expensive piece in the store. Note to guys, don't buy your wife a gun unless she puts it in her hands and gets an idea of how it will feel. Not all internet gun forums are a waste of time. I think one should stay away from larger. My husband and I are on a smaller web forum and there is a lot of good information exchanged between participants. Of course you have the trolls and idiots, but if the site has good moderators they don't stick around long. As for professional training, ask around, talk to the people running the local gun range and yes, the NRA website is helpful. If any women are reading this article and are interested in firearms, I recommend Women in the NRA as a intro course. http://women.nra.org/ They offer courses on firearms, shotguns and 'refuse to be a victim'. Women get together to learn together without being intimidated by men. It is a good starter before you go on the intense professional training.

1.get professional training... Good tip. 2. Buy as good as you can afford...Good idea 3.Intrnet forums...take it all with a grain of salt but knowledge is where you find it and its not exclusive to paid professionals 4.practice...another good tip All good tips and the only way to know how you are going to react when people shoot at you is to have people shoot at you which I hope never happens to anybody...as for caliber I've never seen a box of 22s that didn't have a warning about being dangerous and I wouldn't like having them shot at me. I prefer my RIA 10mm 1911 $600 but my Paraord Expert .45 $427 shoots just as well. And my DB9 $275 seems to work just fine [(]I need to fire it more to be sure[)]. Shoot what you are comfortable with and shoot what you are good with. Guns fit everyone differently. Most ranges have rentals, and I would let my friends or others at the range try mine, find what works for you. That should be tip number 5 Try before you buy.
We shoot all the time in our field [(]yes we have a back stop[)] I have had all calibers and now shoot a Ruger 380,My wife has always shot a 45 acp, My back up.

I like how the first two points are contradictory... 'go to an instructor who's been in a gunfight.' followed by 'military service not important.' I would be willing to bet the average 11B or 0311 is in more gunfights in one deployment than a cop will survive in 30 years on the beat, or the average armed citizen will experience in 10 lifetimes. Let alone some of the 'tier 1' guys out there training people.

For Scott Esse: 'It is sad what these individuals believe is safe and sound advice.' You might as well give up trying to convince some of these people with the facts; it only makes them more stubborn. I attribute their mind set to their outlook in general, that they are invincible. I will predict that now that I have made them aware that a person was actually killed with a BB through the eye, the rush will be on to arm themselves with BB guns. Of course these folks will be excellent shots, making only 'well-placed' eye shots under any and all conditions. The advantages of carrying a BB pistol for self-defense are: guns are cheap, ammunition is cheap, recoil is tolerable, eye shots preclude the need to plow through extra-large bad guys wearing lots of winter clothing, no over-penetration worries, easy on the ears, and, finally, a BB to the brain should be a good stopper so you no longer have to carry around obscene amounts of ammo. The ammunition companies will respond to this new trend by offering BBs that not only penetrate through glasses but then expand to produce devastating internal damage without exiting, thus dumping all their kinetic energy in the target. There will be full-page advertisements showing expansion and penetration tests in ballistic gelatin. But wait, I know what you are thinking, that the bad guys will eventually wise up and start wearing shooting glasses to protect themselves. When that time comes, some of the brighter folks will return to using gun powder to solve their self-defense needs. And, being older and wiser, they will opt for more powerful guns than the mouse guns they used to carry. But, sadly, the diehards will stick with their BB pistols. After all, being under-gunned wasn't a problem in the past, why should they change now.

Point 1. Agree - Good Advice Point 2. Agree - Good Advice Point 3. And this article is different how from an internet blog? Really? So the fact that I found this article through an internet forum should totally discount everything your have to say. 4. Agree Good Advice. 5. Nothing new here, since it's on the internet time to move on.

There are anywhere from several hundred thousand to over a million gun self defense uses in the US each year [(]http://www.guncite.com/gun_control_gcdguse.html[)] The overwhelming majority of these defense uses were people who didn't take a defensive gun course. The beauty of a modern gun is its simplicity and reliability- its not rocket science to use one to save your life when there is no other option. People do remarkable well. Just read the Armed Citizen every month- young and old, male/female, gun pros and gun rookies carry off the task.
Yeah, sure, get all the training you can. But to think that you are helpless without the latest wizbo holster or night sights or defense course is not supported by the real world results obtained by the armed public since the founding of the Republic.

item.title: Mothers and Guns
item.creator: sagi
item.content_encoded: My mother didn’t really have an appreciation for guns. She grew up on a rural farm in Illinois, and the only firearm around the place was a single-shot .22 kept in the barn for varmints. The distance from the house indicates my grandfather didn’t consider it for self-defense. My father, on the other hand, came from a family that put meat on the table during The Great Depression by hunting. He brought to the marriage a few firearms, and with a reluctance that bred respect in my brother and I, mom allowed rifles and shotguns in the house. Handguns never gained the same right. His collection included a sporterized Enfield, a single-shot, bolt-action 12-gauge, a couple of .22 Long Rifles, including a Remington TargetMaster, and, of course, the no-longer-functional Stevens 12-gauge. One of his favorites, though, was a Wards Western Field 16-gauge, pump-action shotgun. It’s nothing fancy-really a Stevens in Montgomery Ward makeup. The manner in which the solid design changed my mother’s opinion on guns is priceless. Dad always told my mother that if a bad guy is breaking into the house and the police are taking forever to arrive, to pump that shotgun once and the perp will run away. It’s really not good advice, especially with today’s all-new generation of drugged perps on the prowl. She always responded with an, “Oh Joe, you worry too much.” He’d shrug, and mark his calendar to deliver the same lecture within a 30-day period. Maybe a year later or so she learned how to work the bolt-release and pump, but refused to load it (she required all firearms to be unloaded in the house, period). Everyone was gone except mom, which is how most of these stories start, and someone started to kick in the kitchen door. Naturally, she called 911, but during her wait the door was falling apart. In desperation, she grabbed the shotgun, returned to the door, declared her intentions to send the perp’s top half to the next county, pumped and heard footsteps. If he was deaf, high, out of his mind or just mean that night, it wouldn’t have ended as nicely. Mom liked that gun ever since and with Mother’s Day this Sunday I had to break it out and give it a good cleaning. Works like new. My mother in law is another story. She loaded her shotgun years ago, and shot the bad guy on the other end of a door in a nearly identical situation. I miss both of them dearly. Happy Mother’s Day! Thankfully, NRA’s Women’s Programs are around today. In fact, signing a loved one up might be the ultimate Mother’s Day gift.
item.excerpt_encoded: Sometimes it takes a bad guy breaking into the house for people to gain an appreciation for guns.

item.title: What's Your Favorite Cartridge?
item.creator: AaronCarter
item.content_encoded: For today’s post, I ask that you to share your favorite handgun or rifle cartridge with your fellow readers. If you’re like me, there are many options that immediately come to mind; however, I invite you to mention just one, and to provide reasoning behind its selection. Some things to consider are: performance, availability, cost, associated firearms, etc. Have fun!
item.excerpt_encoded: What's your favorite cartridge? Share it here.

comment.comment_content: Twenty-two long rifle. My first, and perhaps as I get older and older, my last gun.

My favorite cartridge is the .357 magnum. It's a hot cartridge, but controllable, and comes in a variety of configurations. There are a number of revolvers chambered for this round as well as some rifles, which all can also be used with cheaper .38s for practice. The .357 is a great personal defense round, and can be used for hunting when combined with the right firearm.

My favorite is the .45 ACP. I love the ubiquity of the standard 230 grain load--even at the height of the ammo shortage I could easily find ammo. Knowing that any of my 5,000 rds of .45 ACP can be used as defensive ammo is very comforting. I don't have a long gun, but if and when I get one, it will likely be in .45 ACP. And it is a lot of fun to buy foreign FMJ where the bullet is a little too round and causes slide lock so I can have some practice clearing stoppages. I have 13 M1911s, one Glock 36, and one S&W Thunder Ranch M22-1950. Conveniently, the revolver can be fired without moonclips if you're willing to extract the cases with your fingernail. This is in my opinion the most versatile handgun caliber.
A vote for the 45-70. In a Ruger #3 carbine makes a great, handy combination for swamp and brush deer hunting. And I just like the big ol' brass cartridges.

I agree with the above comments re: the .357 Magnum. My favorite carry gun is a .357 7 shot Taurus Tracker with a 4 in. ported barrel. I feel sorry for any coyote, hog or car jacker that gets too close. One shot in a vital area should do the trick....
300 Win Mag. Accurate, powerful, versatile.

I do not have one favorite cartridge. It depends on what I'm using it for. For a self-defense handgun I'd choose .357 mag, .40 S&W, or 45 ACP. For hunting small game .22 long rifle, or large game .308 Winchester.

7x57mm Mauser.
It was good enough for W.D.M. Bell.
Everything that comes after is a post-script.
7mm08: Very efficient, with light recoil.
Another vote for .357. Very effective in either revolver or rifle. Great cartridge to reload, too. My .357 revolver is probably the most accurate handgun I own!<!--mobile-->
My favorite is the 30-06. The range of bullet weights one can use with it make it extremely versatile.
.204 Ruger. Reaches out as far as I can hit a sage rat, is totally lethal, and so little recoil you can spot your hits.
My all time favorite was the 6 mm Remington. This gun would devastate groundhogs! <!--mobile-->
The 6mm PPC is my favorite uses a small powder charge, and is the most accurate cartridge made

.45 ACP. It is: Easy to reload. Widely available in excellent commercial loadings. Not 'hard' on handguns and 'brass'. Accurate in the various pistols I shoot [(]FNH, Colt, Kimber[)]. A good defensive cartridge.

For varmints, the 22-250 with a 50 grain bullet @ 4000fps--you can see the varmint disappear before the gun jumps; king of the 22 caliber bullets--leaves no wounded varmints to limp away, and a Vmax tip will blow open/ knock down coyotes at 200+ yards. My longest kill shot is only 243 yards on a g-hog, but here in eastern Ohio the pastures, farms, hills and woods don't offer long shots like out west. The rifle barrel is light weight too! But now since Buckeyes can shoot deer this year with high caliber brush guns my choice might change--not. Varmint tags and seasons are unlimited and so is the fun; deer shots are tag limited in number and season.--Leo
Shot my first deer with .30 rem, can get brass for it now and can reload. 8mm Mauser and .45/70 But really love my blackpowder front stuffers .

I think this is a trick question. You might as well ask 100 million kids what is your favorite ice cream or toy. They are all just great and i love all the ones that i can get my hands on best. At 5 years old it was the 22 short rimfire when on vacation i was allowed one 50 round box and a single shot rifle to shoot with under adult supervision. Over the years there have been many toys and flavors and interest change over time. Right now i have really started appreciating the .243 Winchester. It covers a broad range of uses, doesn't beat you up so you can practice more and it is accurate as hell. One day soon i will look back in the toy box with a renewed interest in some other toy or go to the toy store and buy another.
My favorite cartridge is 45 colt in my Winchester 94.

item.title: Ruger SR-762
item.creator: staff
item.content_encoded: A few years back, Ruger admitted that it was time to enter the burgeoning AR-style rifle market. Rather than reproducing another gas-impingement platform, the company produced its own AR shooting system, which operated using a patented, chrome-plated, two-stage piston with a multi-stage regulator. That first AR-style rifle, dubbed the SR-556, was chambered in .223 Rem. and was well received by the shooting community. Our latest Gun of the Week, however, isn’t the SR-556. It’s the next step in the evolution of Ruger’s AR-style platform, chambered in .308-and it’s known as the SR-762. The 762 is a re-design of the 556, beefed up to handle the larger  .308 cartridges. That said, the gun looks and feels very similar – in reality, it’s only a little bit more than a half-pound heavier than it’s “little” brother. Its steel components are treated with a non-reflective, black manganese-phosphate finish, while the aluminum components are finished in a matte, hard-coat anodizing to match. Like the 556, it sports a barrel that measures just over 16 inches, and it arrives with a 556-style flash suppressor already in place. For more information, check out the video embedded below, hosted by Managing Online Editor Shawn Skipper, or go to Ruger.com. Technical Specifications: Action: Two-Stage Piston Gas Operated Semi-Auto Caliber: .308 Win./7.62 NATO Finish: Manganese Phosphate/Hard Coat Anodized Sights: Adjustable AR-Type Folding Iron Sights Barrel Length: 16.12” Overall Length: 34.75” to 38” Length of Pull: 11.5” to 14.75” Height: 8” Weight: 8.6 lbs. Twist: 1:10” RH Rifle Grooves: 6 MSRP: $2,195 For Further Reading: • Review: Ruger SR-762 • Ruger Introduces the SR-762 • SHOT Show 2014: SR-762 Rifle Multimedia:
item.excerpt_encoded: Ruger takes its popular piston-operated AR semi-auto rifle to the next level by chambering it for the .308 Win./7.62 NATO cartridge.

comment.comment_content: Too bad that Nagpur changed design for .308 Pmags. They no longer work with this rifle. Other than being heavy, it shoots well. Finish is nice. Why does ruger keep using that crappy looking flash suppressor. <!--mobile-->
Have had one for 6 months and love the gun. Well made! Have have no problem with different ammo and have added a scope to it leaving the iron sites on it. Low recoil even with nato rounds.
Why bother? A m14/M1A weighs about the same in standard model uses a piston design already proven and is available in 16 inch barrel model too. Just curious what is MOA using FGGM match ammo with it?

Dan, I have the same question. If I were to spring $2,200 or more for a semi-auto rifle, I would seriously consider an M14. In either case, weight is a large consideration, but tipping the scales toward the AR-15 platform, I like the comfort of the pistol grip, rather than the traditional grip of the M14. Accuracy-wise, I have no idea which rifle would take t he honors.
Springfield Armory puts out some nice M14s, and if I someday decide to look seriously at a semi-auto in .308, I will have to spend some time doing a comparo.

Not to nitpick, but the SR-556 is actually chambered in 5.56mm, not .223.
As to why choose the SR-762 over the M14 - if you have served in the military and used the M16/M4-series rifles, then you have zero train up for the rifle. If you have not served and have not used or own an AR-15-type rifle, then the M14 would make a fine choice.
Just my thoughts!

Got one of these a couple weeks ago and it's awesome! Changed the stock and grip, added a Vortex optic and have had ZERO issues with Pmags. Doesn't care what ya feed it either - just a great shooting rifle. I smoothed out the rather stiff [(]7.5 #[)] trigger and have no bad things to say. I'll probably put a different trigger in, but that's just me.

I got one and have had jamming problems from the beginning. Someone said it must be the ammo. I say I have a mini-14 I've used all kinds of ammo in with no problems. I also have an M1A that I've used the exact same ammo with no problems. I have sent the rifle back to the factory hoping they can find out the problem.
I live in Queens NY. Where can I purchase one? Do I need to go to Ruger for the purchase?

item.title: Snapshots: When Taxidermy Attacks
item.creator: keefe
item.content_encoded: First off, congratulations to the winner of the inaugural edition of Snapshots, Joe Neuburger. Joe took home first prize with the following submission: "Joe Biden says if that big shiney thing gets any closer, we're to fire two warning shots, but not to hurt it with our bayonets." Joe, we'll be in touch. Now, without further ado, we offer you "When Taxidermy Attacks." From The pages of American Rifleman’s predecessor, Arms & the Man, Art Director David Labrozzi found this gem. Before Photoshop, it was hard to create dramatic  action photos with wild animals. As evidenced here, it was apparently really hard. The original caption read: “A Chance for Backwoods Surgery.” Good, very good. But we think you can do better. Keep it clean. Bloomberg probably pays an intern minimum wage to read this blog. Entries will be subjectively judged by staff editors between takes of the TV show, testing guns and making authors seem literate. The winner and others we deem worthy will be printed here. All judgments final. No returns. This week’s special guest judge is Art David Director David Labrozzi, who contributed this week’s no doubt highly sought after prize. No need to hit the box under my desk this week. We offer the snarkiest writer the scarce and desirable NRA “shot” glass. The gun depicted on this object d’art appears to have the back half of a Derringer and two malformed barrels of a LeMat in the front. It’s possible the artisan was drinking when he or she created this. At one time, someone over at the NRA store thought this was a really, really good idea. Object is in fair condition with light staining. No idea what liquid may have been in there at one time, but vestiges of it remain. Object is given away “as is” with original patina. We have no idea of whether it is dishwasher safe or not. Official Snapshots Rules: • Caption submissions must be made in the comments section of this blog, or on the corresponding Facebook post. • One winner will be chosen, selected by Mark Keefe or a randomly selected guest judge. • Keep it clean, folks. Next Week: Definitely Not Legal For Sale In California, Okay Probably Not
