item.title: Don’t Overlook the Shoulder Holster
item.creator: JimWilson
item.content_encoded: There was a time when the shoulder holster seemed to be required equipment for all police detectives, P.I.’s, sleuths and all sorts of plainclothes operatives. In recent times it has taken a back seat to the various other carry methods. In truth, the shoulder rig is not as fast as a good holster worn on the strong-side hip, and the straps of the unit can often cause fatigue to the shoulder muscles after a long day of wearing a heavy handgun. However, it should not be overlooked by today’s handgunners, as it may be just the ticket for certain defensive carry situations. A person who spends most of his day sitting may find the shoulder holster to be much handier, not to mention more comfortable, than the hip holster. I often wear one when driving on a long trip because it makes my defensive handgun easier to get to while I'm seated in my vehicle. I also find it is not as fatiguing as the hip holster that seems to be jammed between my hip and the car seat. While in law enforcement, I generally carried a Colt Commander on my right hip. But, in addition to that pistol, I had an identical Colt Commander in a shoulder holster stowed under the seat of my vehicle. In the case of a serious incident, I could quickly slip on the shoulder rig and have two identical handguns to deal with any dangerous situation that might present itself. Whether you use a horizontal shoulder holster or one of the traditional vertical rigs is entirely a matter of personal preference. Just remember that you will need a covering garment that opens to the front, such as a sport coat or a zippered jacket. A pull-over garment is effective cover, but it will really slow down the pistol presentation. Keep in mind that it is important to practice presenting the pistol from the shoulder holster. The position of your support hand will be different than it is in the strong-side presentation. This is because the support hand and arm must be out of the way during the presentation to avoid covering yourself with the muzzle of your own handgun. As with all other defensive carry methods, the shoulder holster is not for everyone. However, it should be a consideration for many concealed-carry permit holders, because it just might meet your personal defense needs as no other carry method can.
item.excerpt_encoded: Although the shoulder holster has taken a back seat to various other carry methods, don't overlook it as a viable concealed-carry option.

comment.comment_content: One disadvantage not often discussed: a good holster/carry position should be easy to 'defend' against those people who are obnoxiously touchy-feely. You know, those members of your church who don't know how to express their love for others without rubbing you all over the shoulders and patting the small of your back. For example, if a man offers his right hand to shake hands while extending his left hand to touch you, just grab his left hand with your right hand as if to say 'yes, let's all hold hands and praise the Lord!' [(]If a woman does it, you're probably not at church.[)] When confronted with the more common 'shoulder/back rubber,' a shoulder holster's straps could be easily felt even under a wool jacket. Of course, he might not realize what it is, but having had one person ask me if I carry a piece, I'm not letting it happen again.
The Galco Classic Lite or Miami Classic are perfect. Anyone not considering a shoulder holster is short changing themselves.

I must respectfully but strongly disagree about vertical v. horizontal being personal preference. Horizontal shoulder holsters can easily dump your handgun as you run or even walk. Retention snaps can easily come unsnapped from dozens of causes. If the gun is loose enough for you to draw it, it is also loose enough to get jostled out. My .357 SIG P239 auto FELL OUT of my expensive name brand horizontal shoulder holster during a foot pursuit. If it makes you feel better, you can tell yourself that I didn’t use it properly or that it was in some other way my fault. Good luck.

item.title: The Most Famous Rifle Of D-Day … Wasn’t There?
item.creator: keefe
item.content_encoded: Based on Cornelius Ryan’s Longest Day, the epic Hollywood blockbuster of the same name featured actor Peter Lawford carrying what is arguably the most famous rifle of Operation Overlord. The problem is that that rifle, made famous by Hollywood, wasn’t there on June 6 1944. Lawford played Simon Fraser, the 17th Baron Lovat and the 25th chief of the clan Frasier. Winston Churchill called Lovat, “the mildest-mannered man that ever scuttled a ship or cut a throat.” Lord Lovat was one of the first volunteers for the Commando units formed in 1940, and his first combat action with No. 4 Commando was in 1941. And it was no coincidence that much of the highly specialized training the commandos received was undertaken in the highlands of Scotland. On the Dieppe Raid in August 1942-a disaster whose lessons paved the way for the success of Operation Overlord, Lord Lovat carried his personal Mannlicher-Shoenauer carbine. You can see it along with an M1911 Government Model on his hip. He was hunter and a Lord, and as such, he decided to bring his own rifle from home. On D-Day, Brigadier Lord Lovat, Distinguished Service Order, commanded the First Special Service Brigade and landed on Sword Beach. The brigade’s objective was to move the six miles inland and link up with Major John Howard’s D Company of the 2nd Oxfordshire & Buckinghamshire Light Infantry, their sappers and troopers of 7 Para holding the bridges, thus shutting off the route to beaches for a German counterattack. Major Howard’s capture of “Pegasus Bridge” was one of the most important military feats of D-Day. In one of D-Day’s most iconic images, you can see Lord Lovat’s lanky frame over the shoulder of Bill Millen, his personal piper, wading into the surf. Lovat wrote: “The water was knee-deep when Piper Millin struck up ‘Blue Bonnets,’ keeping the pipes going as he played the commandos up the beach. It was not a place to hang about in, and we stood not on the order of our going.” And it was the sound of Millen’s bagpipes that the relived airborne troops heard at the link up. It’s a great story, and one of the best vignettes of the movie The Longest Day. The problem is that Lord Lovat-according to his autobiography March Past and the current owner of his Mannlicher-carried a different rifle that day. And like the Gillies he grew up with and the commandoes he trained, Lord Lovat actually did a bit of stalking, but of “Jerry,” on the way. In the battle for St. Aubin on the way to Pegasus Bridge, Lovat wrote: “The enemy-a platoon about thirty strong--looked a soft touch: the sun was in their eyes and we were unobserved.  I made a quick decision to ambush them. It was a relief to get the rucksack off-straps were already burning shoulders--then tee up behind its bulk and go into action with a light, short-barreled U.S. Army carbine. Joe Lawrence and Salsbury’s brother, a dispatch rider, sneaked one of the quick-firing [Vickers] K Guns up on to a shed. The Germans were five hundred yards away. We had not been seen. They were in the bag.” So Hollywood, as is so often the case, had it wrong about Lord Lovat and his Mannlicher that day. Lord Lovat actually carried a U.S. Carbine, Caliber .30. But for this error--and a few others in otherwise excellent and important film, Hollywood can be forgiven. Lovat, by the way, was wounded on the attack on Breville on June 12, ending his combat service. He died in 1995. I’d like to close this post by noting and honoring the supreme sacrifice made by the soldiers, sailors and airmen-regardless of their country or rank--that gave all to secure the Freedoms we enjoy today a half a world away 70 years ago this day. Lest we forget …
item.excerpt_encoded: When Lord Lovat led his British Commandos into Normandy on June 6, 1944, he carried his trademark Mannlicher-Shoenauer carbine across Sword Beach, right? Not so fast. Here's what he really carried.

comment.comment_content:
'the Dieppe Raid in August 1942-a disaster whose lessons paved the way for the success of Operation Overlord'
This is a myth perpetuated to take the sting out of the disaster. The North African, Sicilian, Salerno and Anzio amphibious operations all occurred after Dieppe and before Normandy. Amphibious operations in the Pacific- the Solomons and Tarawa also took place before D-Day.
Apart from other opportunities to learn about amphibious operations the fact that Dieppe was to be a raid and not an invasion- with all the logistics problems that entailed- made the idea that it was some sort of trial run preposterous. The notion that the allies learned not to launch day light frontal attacks on defended ports- while obvious was ignored in Torch where the US attacked two French held ports at great cost but successfully.
The Dieppe Raid's aims were really to give the head of Combined Operations- Lord Louis Mountbatten- one last big raid before he went to take over in Burma. The 2nd Canadian Division was chosen as the main landing force largely to make up for the Canadian Army not yet engaging the Germans in any meaningful way [(]1st Canadian division would land in Sicily in 1943[)].

item.title: Six Things to Consider When Choosing Self-Defense Handgun Ammunition
item.creator: AaronCarter
item.content_encoded: Before you purchase personal-protection ammunition, contemplate the following items. Only then can you make an informed decision about what load best suits your unique set of demands. Price: Honestly answer this question: What value do you place on your life, or those of your family members? I would wager that it’s more than the $1 to $1.50 cost of a defense-specific round that could potentially preserve your-or your family’s-wellbeing. As such, ignore the price tag; instead, focus on the loads’ performance parameters and whether or not they meet your demands. Expectations: Where do you live? From where do you anticipate a threat to emerge? What measures are you willing to take to stop a threat? The answers to these questions will narrow the field of suitable options considerably. Do you want your ammunition to be able to defeat “light” barriers, such as clothing, or be “barrier blind,” and clean house through the much-vaunted “FBI protocol?” Bullets well suited for the former generally perform poorly against “hard” barriers; however, their advantages include: reduced risk of over-penetration, increased energy dispersion and, in the case of a miss, rapid deceleration upon striking an object. Loads fitting this description are Federal’s Guard Dog, Hornady’s Critical Defense, and Liberty Ammunition’s Civil Defense. Typically, these loads feature light-for-caliber bullets and, if a lead core is utilized, it is not bonded to the jacket. Projectiles that are designed specifically to meet the stringent FBI protocol penetrate deep and readily defeat various types of barriers; however, they can result in over-penetration and are more difficult to stop with an outright miss. They do, however, offer consistency with regard to depth of penetration, expansion, and weight retention. Such loads include: Hornady Critical Duty, Federal HST and Hydra-Shok, Speer Gold Dot, Winchester Bonded PDX1 and Defend, Barnes TAC-XPD, Nosler Defense, Cor-Bon DPX, and Remington Ultimate Defense and Golden Saber, among others. Construction runs the gamut in this category; some feature all-copper projectiles whereas others have gilding metal jackets bonded to lead cores. Still, some have hard, lead-alloy cores with a gilding metal jacket secured via simple, yet ingenuous, “mechanical” lock. Between these two categories is found a myriad of loads that offer some combination of the aforementioned performance parameters. These include: Hornady Custom, HPR, and Fiocchi loaded with the Hornady XTP, PMC Starfire, and Federal Personal Defense (JHPs). Lastly, unless employing them for a specific reason, avoid the use of standard, non-expanding FMJ loads for personal protection, as many of the disadvantages of FBI-“protocol”-type bullets previously described are exacerbated, and there is minimal energy dispersion and reduced tissue disruption. Reliability: Reliability is paramount in a defensive load; the ammunition must feed, fire, extract, and eject every time in your handgun. Of course, this cannot be determined at the time of purchase, but chances are, by reading and comparing reviews of the ammunition from various magazines, websites, and forums, as well as the talking with knowledgeable range and gun store staff, you will garner enough feedback about suitable (and unsuitable) handgun/ammunition combinations to make an informed buying decision. Also, double-check the owner’s manual to see if there are preferred (or required) ammunition types and bullet weights and profiles. Adhere to these suggestions for both safety and optimal performance. Lastly, spend time at the range confirming the compatibility of your chosen ammunition with handgun. Do not rely on an unproven combo. Velocity: Trajectory and energy aren’t the primary concerns surrounding velocity; rather, that, in your gun, the bullet attains sufficient speed to reliably upset is the foremost consideration. Bullets are designed to work within a specific window of velocities, and deviating from that range can cause the projectile to fail to expand (i.e. acting as a FMJ), over-expand, thereby reducing penetration, and even experience jacket-core separation or unintended fragmentation. The former is most evident in compact “pocket” pistols, which, due to their abbreviated barrel lengths, lack sufficient velocity to ensure expansion-especially if the hollow-point cavity is clogged. Many major ammunition manufacturers now have options that are designed to mitigate this concern. Some examples are: Hornady Critical Defense, Remington Ultimate Defense Compact Handgun, and Speer Gold Dot Short Barrel. For full-size handguns, relaible expansion shouldn’t be an issue. And, unless you’re using a handgun with an abnormally long barrel (or pistol caliber-chambered carbine), exceeding the upper velocity limitations of a self-defense bullet would be unlikely. Accuracy: This is purely subjective. Does your ammunition/handgun combination need to be able to shoot 1” groups at 25 yds. to stop a threat? Perhaps, I suppose. Or is 5” to 6” adequate? Maybe somewhere between is okay. What about at 7 yds. with a “pocket” pistol? Is 2” sufficient? The reality is, in the pursuit of achieving phenomenal accuracy, you might eliminate a load that otherwise ideally meets your performance parameters. Choose wisely. Cases: Nickel-plated or brass cases? Is there a difference? Most “premium” defensive-specific loads now feature nickel-plated cases. The reported benefits are: enhanced corrosion resistance, easier viewing (magazine and press checks) in low-light conditions, and improved feeding. If you rotate defense loads at least annually, even if you carry daily in high-moisture environments (i.e. primarily the eastern half of the U.S., Midwest, and Northwest coast) or concealed (legally) in high-perspiration areas of your body, nickel-plated cases are likely unnecessary; however, improved visibility in compromised lighting is a real benefit. As for functioning, I’ve seen no discernible difference in the feeding reliability between nickel-plated and standard brass cases. But, since nickel-plated cases are pretty much standard on defense-specific loads, consider it a bonus. By no means is this list all-inclusive; for example, one could also consider recoil (full power vs. reduced-recoil). But, hopefully this gives you some food for thought. It’s a potentially life-saving decision that shouldn’t be made haphazardly.
item.excerpt_encoded: Getting ready to buy self-defense handgun ammunition? Read this first.

comment.comment_content: What a luxury to be able to choose what type of ammo to use...many of us are still stuck with 'whatever they happen to have on the shelf today' and are happy to get FMJ hardball.

I've noticed that the wide-mouth hollow point bullets have more weight in the rear than the front, making them dynamically unstable. At 25 yrds they are likely to tumble, and may be traveling sideways or backwards by the time they reach the target. Up close they work as advertized but at longer distances accuracy and expansion isn't very good.

No matter how bad the ammo shortages have been, the self defense ammo seemed to always be on the shelves... On a rare occasion was I put in a spot where I'd not be able to purchase the larger named SD ammo of my choosing.
If you're in a 'green' State, then you have my condolences.<!--mobile-->

Lots of good information here but, unfortunately, not a bottom line. Expectations: Tell me which bad guy will show up and I will know which weapon to bring. Perhaps a pellet gun for 80-year-old Gramps armed with a cane, the .380 to scare away the unarmed mugger, the 9mm for the wimp dressed in a t-shirt armed only with a knife, or the .40/10mm/.45 for everyone else. Rule #2: Bring Enough Gun. Reliability: Only a center fire, never a rim fire. And it has to feed 100 percent of the time. Velocity: You WANT all the expansion you can get but you NEED sufficient penetration. The only way to increase velocity is to burn more powder and/or increase the length of the barrel. The only way to increase penetration is to limit expansion or increase the payload. But are you really up to shooting a .41 or .44 Magnum loaded with medium-weight quick-expanding bullets? Probably not so reduce the Magnum down to the maximum you can handle. Don't go down too far or you will end up with a wimpy feel-good mouse gun. Accuracy: You will have to be the judge of that. Cases: Makes no difference. Rifle shooters have known for a long time that if you have to choose between two different weight bullets, you will never go wrong with the heavier bullet. And, a heavier bullet will make up for 'bad' bullet performance simply because it has the weight to plow through. The FBI proved to their satisfaction that a 40 caliber bullet weighing 180 grains traveling at over 1200 fps was the ideal medicine for all bad guys, regardless of how they presented. They settled for a little less than 1000 fps. Your house gun can have a longer barrel to increase velocity and weigh more to subdue the recoil of a more powerful cartridge. Your carry gun is the challenge because it will probably be smaller yet you have to have the power to take on all bad guys, not just Gramps and his cane.

I agree with Pete; if you can't count on replacing your ammo with the same load next time, it's probably not a good idea. This rules out 'law enforcement only' loads unless you are sure that your source will get more in. I carry a short-barrelled .45 ACP so I operate under the assumption that the bullet won't expand. For that reason as well as controllability, I avoid the modern, hotter loads and instead rely on generic Winchester white box JHP or its Bass Pro version SXZ. It gives good accuracy out of a 3-inch barrel, is highly reliable, shoots the same as practice ammo, and is cheap enough to fill several of my guns. On the other hand, it creates a fireball when fired in the dark. I only have one disagreement with the author--most magazine articles and forums are useless. Most gun writers won't say anything that could reflect poorly on a future source of ad revenue; and internet forums are full of people who will blame their malfunctions on equipment rather than their own limp-wristing, failure to clean the gun, or using reloaded ammo.

I use FMJ in all my handguns. I have never had a FTF/FTE, It is good enough for me. I do pay premium prices for my hunting ammo, [(]Barnes[)]. I am an old guy and just can't chase the newest fad handgun loads. If I need real firepower my AR is only a short reach away.

How many people actually test their ammo to see how much it expands and how deeply it penetrates or have acutally hunted with it and shot live animals. Answer, probably less than 1 per cent but most choose to believe the archaic caliber myths ad nauseam.
Example: U.S. testing on the .45 acp in 1945 showed the .45 lacked sufficient penetration to even defeat a WWII helmet at a scant 35 yards versus the 9mm which went into the helmet at an incredible 125 yards.
The .30 Mauser out penetrated the .357 magnum when shooting into water.
The .32 acp out penetrated the .380 auto when the German army tested them that's why the adopted the .32 acp over the .380.
The heart will stop when hit by a .177 caliber air pellet or when hit by a 20mm cannon.
Expansion sometimes stops a bullet before it penetrates deeply enough to reach vital organs if the bullet is too light in weight.
Heavy bullets often over penetrate and kill innocent bystanders.
Larger diameter bullets often penetrate less than smaller diameter bullets that often travel at higher velocities and ditto for expansion as well.
The 6.5 Mannlicher bullet of 160 grains at 2,300 fps was known to out penetrate all of the large bore elephant calibers of the early 1900's.
Conclusion: Depending on the range, the weight of the bullet , the velocity of the bullet, what the bullet is made of, the diameter of the bullet, what type of material the bullet encounters such as clothing or bone or soft tissue will determine if the bullet expands or penetrates or reaches vital organs, none of which can often be predetermined and the myth that larger calibers are always better has been proven false over 100 years ago and is still true to this very day.

Just a couple thoughts...[(]1[)] revolvers don't have 'feed' problems, and [(]2[)] nobody mentioned Glaser Safety Rounds for urban situations where you don't want the possibility of collaterial damage in the next room.
If you practice all year long with re-loads, your point-of-aim will be quite different at 25 yds with factory loads. Pay attention to the difference.

I pretty much agree - the most important thing is, whatever you use, do NOT use handloads or you could find yourself at the wrong end of a civil court case involving 'loading your own 'Nazi killer' bullets intended to kill...'. Use factory loads and preferably known loads or bullet types commonly used by your local PD. If the bad guy or guys are close enough to fire at, beyond a certain point, bullet types aren't going to matter a huge amount in typical handgun ammunition. Are the bad guy[(]s[)] on drugs or alcohol? Trust me - differences between bullet types will be even less noticeable - WHERE you place your shots and multiple hits will do you in much greater stead rather than 'did you use the latest 'whiz-bang' H/P...!<!--mobile-->

Handgun effectiveness depends on penetration, which also is related to momentum [(]Mass x velocity[)]. I am not at all uncomfortable using the heaviest bullet I can get in a caliber that starts with .4 in a FMJ configeration. I get the bonus of proven reliability in my Glock pistols, and also understand that I must rely on bullet placement. I feel that loading high dollar rounds may lead to a false sense of security. I really want the most penetration I can get. I have seen many people who are far more than 14' thick, and I want thru - thru 2 arms and 2 lungs plus bones plus anything else in the way!

Handgun effectiveness depends on penetration, which also is related to momentum [(]Mass x velocity[)]. I am not at all uncomfortable using the heaviest bullet I can get in a caliber that starts with .4 in a FMJ configeration. I get the bonus of proven reliability in my Glock pistols, and also understand that I must rely on bullet placement. I feel that loading high dollar rounds may lead to a false sense of security. I really want the most penetration I can get. I have seen many people who are far more than 14' thick, and I want thru - thru 2 arms and 2 lungs!

That we are prepared to defend our families and ourselves is a good thing. Loading to be able to blast holes all the way to our neighbor's home is just plain stupid and quite unnecessary. You are responsible for what you unleash- which hopefully will never wind up going through some innocent person's bedroom, etc. Few of us other than LEO's will ever need to be able to nail a violent offender through a windshield. The defense rounds would be far more appropriate than the service rounds for 95[%] of us.

If it misses, it's the shooter's fault. If it don't go 'BANG', it could be the round or the pistol, but it's still the shooter who has to catch up and get back ahead of the other guys' OODA loop. Training is #1. Shoot what you train with is your best bet. For me, that's FMJ. A hit with a .22 beats a miss with a .44.

For me, aiming in a quick scenario is as much importance as what ammo you chose.I do use top grade ammo. All my self defense pistols are autos and have Crimson Trace laser sights. Over the past few years i trained myself to point and shot using the lasers, not the sights. Now i can instinct shoot within 30 to 50 feet without bringing the gun up to look through the sights. Whether from my hip,waist, stomach or chest i am dead on every time. Even laying down. The targets i practice with are anywhere from 4 inch to man size and i feel i could stop anybody set to do me or mine any great bodily harm.

I'm sorry, but the comment about accuracy of bullets which have more weight to the rear is BS. I've seen .44, .45 & even .22 cal pistols shoot accurately over 100 yards. When a bullet slows down in a target media, they tend to reverse to heavy end forward.
Has there ever been a law suit over a shooting because reloads were used? This topic has been kicking around since the '70's that I know of...
The best ammo is what you can buy, shoots accurately enough in your weapon and can penetrate to vitals to inflict enough damage to stop the fight.
Shoot at least twice - there's a 50-50 chance your hollow point won't expand or you FMJ just deflected off under the skin. You'd be surprised at the amount of damage it takes to stop some folks.
Large vs small diameter: Large holes damage a greater cross section of tissue. More damage means a higher chance of stopping the target. More weight means deeper penetration. Shoot a bullet heavy enough to reach major organs on your biggest target.
LEO ammo standards should be your starting point.

Would you like to read about some autopsies? 'Yes, the 9mm and .380 are the rounds I most often see on the autopsy table, but they're also the rounds that usually require multiple hits to make the kill. The standing joke in the morgue is to guess the caliber by looking at the x-rays. If multiple rounds show up on the x-rays more often than not it's a 9mm or .380 [(]or .32 or .25 or some mouse gun caliber[)]. If only one round shows up, it could be an inordinately good hit with a .380 or 9mm, but more likely it's a .40 or .45. Yes, the .380 and 9mm will do the job, but usually multiple hits are required as opposed to single hits with a .40 or .45. Ballistic gelatin, being all that's available for most bullet testing, is good as far as it goes but it's often far different from what we see in the morgue. A far more realistic scenario would be to dress up ballistic gelatin with a heavy coat of denim to mimic blue jeans, embed some bones obtained from a butcher shop, and throw in a few objects of varying densities to mimic organs. Try it again, and I think you'll see that this impressive wound cavity that's so often seen in ballistic gelatin goes down the tubes. The human body isn't just composed of one density as ballistic gelatin is, and the bullet does various things to various parts of the body as it passes through. And that's why I think observations from a morgue are so important. So let me give a few thoughts here. First, as you've pretty well guessed by now, I'm a big fan of the .40 and .45 for personal defense, and for the same reasons. They're both big, slow-moving bullets. Of the two, I think big is more important. As I've said before, I want something that will plow through bone and keep going, not skip off of it. I can't tell you how many times I've seen a .380 or 9mm strike bone on a well-placed shot and skip off in a non-vital direction, leaving the BG free to return fire. With the .40 and .45, this seldom happens. Bone is in the body for basically two reasons--to give support as with the legs and spinal column and to protect major organs, such as the ribs protecting the heart or the skull protecting the brain. Skip a bullet off a support bone, such as the leg, and the BG will keep shooting. Break it, like you generally do with a .40 or .45, and the BG is going to hit the pavement and your chances of survival increase dramatically. It's the same with a shot to the chest. Skip a 9mm off the sternum [(]breastbone[)] and the fight continues; plow through the sternum with a .45 and, trust me, the fight is over. I'm just convinced that all things being equal, bigger is better when it comes to bullet size. I also like bullets to expend all their energy in the body, not only for the protection of nearby civilians, but because I think it imparts more damage. I'm a bit less certain of this one, however, than I am about bullet size. Whether a bullet remains in the body is often as much a result of WHERE in the body it hit as what it was hit with. If hit solely in tissue, more often than not the bullet exits the body, regardless of what caliber it was; bone, on the other hand, can slow the bullet dramatically and leave it lodged in the body. As for the .357 being a well-documented man-stopper, I'm guessing that it's mainly a function of velocity, but if someone wants to disagree I'll have no issue with it because it's a caliber we almost NEVER see anymore. When I was a cop in Atlanta it was the caliber of choice for law enforcement. Unfortunately, I only rarely got to see autopsies back then so I can't speak from vast experience. With the increasing use of semi-autos, the prevalence of revolver rounds such as the .38 and .357 has dropped dramatically, and although we still see the .38 with some frequency, we almost never get to see the .357 at autopsy. Still, in its most lethal form, it's a 125-grain bullet, the same as a 9mm in many cases, and the 9mm has a horrible reputation as a reliable man-stopper. Again, I'm only guessing that it's a function of the higher velocity of the .357.'

Thomas wrote: 'I've noticed that the wide-mouth hollow point bullets have more weight in the rear than the front, making them dynamically unstable. At 25 yrds they are likely to tumble, and may be traveling sideways or backwards by the time they reach the target.'
This displays a stunning level of ignorance of external ballistics. The most accurate bullets made by bullet manufacturers are the OTM type, which are specifically designed to bias the weight toward the rear.

Big Foot wrote: 'quote' It only takes one hit with a .40 or .45 to make a stop but it takes multiple shoots with a 9mm.'
Baloney. Did Bigfoot every consider the fact that most 9mm's that are carried are high capacity and due to the fact that they kick less the shooter is able to put multiple rounds on target as apposed to only one with the harder kicking .40 and .45. Does Bigfoot think that a mere 1/10 of an inch in diameter between th 9mm and .45 makes such a big difference? What a joke.

For Petrusova: I didn't write any of that, I just passed it on for what it was worth. Sometimes it pays to listen to fact instead of opinion. But let me try to defend what he learned from the autopsy table. Your argument about the ability to make multiple hits with the 9 is quite common on this site. That scenario assumes that you get to fill the BG full of lead at your convenience. But what if he is raising his weapon to fire at you and you only have time to get off one shot? Or that he is moving and you only get one shot before he makes cover? And what if your one round hits the sternum or a rib and 'skips off' and doesn't count? You just have to ask yourself, would I be more likely to be the winner with a 9 or something bigger in a fight where the first shot was the only one that mattered. And for your other question about diameter, it's the weight that is inherent to diameter that drives the bullet deep through clothes, skin, bone, tissue, and organs. The bonus is that it makes a bigger hole on its trip. Momentum [(]weight X velocity[)] favors heavy bullets and that's why he reported that the .40 and .45 busted through everything and quickly ended the fight. You just have to accept the fact that a .40, 10mm. or .45 provides better life insurance than a 9mm because they have a better chance of ending the fight with that most important round, the first one.

If you're in the deep wilderness and attacked by a grizzly bear you'll probably want a 454, 460 S&W, 500 S&W or 480 Ruger on your belt. If you are buying ammunition for defense against a human criminal the ideal weapon is a Star Trek phaser on stun. But such doesn't exisit, we are stuck with a conventional handgun. The task is not to kill the atacker but to hit him/her so hard they are unable to perform any aggressive action. A bullet that causes the desirable shock but doesn't require dozens of hits that may be fatal but don't rupture the lungs and heart, or destroy the liver or kidneys. A bullet with weight [[]mass], a blunt or deforming profile that breaks bones and will stop in the human torso most of the time is desirable. The convenient 380 and 32 ACP guns require precise bullet placement. The 9x19 mm [[]Luger] now has a proven track record, the 45 ACP has 100 years if history as a fight stopper. The 40 S&W and 10mm are newer but still have a record of successful use in combat. Often the 380 and 32 ACP are in such small size they are hard to shoot well. The market has well designed guns and there is now good ammo, often at $1.00 per round. Any gun must be demonstrated to function with the chosen ammunition, that can be expensive, but how much is your life worth and the life of your spouse and children?

item.title: The Armed Citizen® June 8, 2014
item.creator: staff
item.content_encoded: Tariq Bell and his 13-year-old daughter had just left a music store when they were approached by a 40-year-old stranger. The man had just robbed someone at a nearby hotel and was being pursued by police. The fugitive grabbed Bell from behind, jumped into the driver's seat of his vehicle and demanded the keys. With his daughter already in the backseat of the vehicle, Bell acted quickly. He drew his firearm and ordered the man to get out of his vehicle. When the fugitive saw Bell's gun, he fled. It was reported that he then tried to carjack another victim who sped away. He was, however, successful in carjacking a third victim and led police on a high speed chase. He was ultimately apprehended and faces charges including armed robbery, carjacking, kidnapping and aggravated assault on a police officer. Neither Bell nor his daughter was injured during the incident. (WSB Radio, Snellville, Ga., 11/13/13) Around 9 p.m., a resident was approached by two men outside of his home. The men carried firearms and ordered the resident into his own home. The man was pistol whipped by the suspects as they demanded money from him. While inside the home, the resident was able to get his own firearm and fired in self-defense. One suspect reportedly returned fire, but missed. Both suspects then fled the scene. Police caught up to the assailants soon thereafter. One suspect was taken to the hospital with a gunshot wound, but later died of his injuries. The second suspect was arrested and charged with armed robbery and conspiracy to commit armed robbery. (WBTV, Charlotte, N.C., 5/13/14) From The Armed Citizen® Archives February 1960: After buying $2 worth of gas at a service station near Bowie, Md., the customer pointed a gun at attendant Gilbert Roy Gertz and said, "Give me what you've got in your pocket." Gertz reached in, pulled out a cal. .25 pistol, and killed the bandit with a single shot. (The Washington Daily News, Bowie, Md.)
item.excerpt_encoded: Read three more amazing stories of self-defense in the latest online edition of The Armed Citizen®.

comment.comment_content: i love reading these articles.
I like reading about people being able to defend themselves w/o the need to call for outside assistance. <!--mobile-->
I love stories that have happy endings such as those! <!--mobile-->

item.title: Remington Model 700 Ultimate Muzzleloader
item.creator: staff
item.content_encoded: One of the showstoppers at the 143rd NRA Annual Meetings & Exhibits was the Remington Model 700 Ultimate Muzzleloader. The company unveiled its new smokepole in front of a crowd of more than 75,000 attendees, calling the gun's Accelerated Muzzleloader Performance (AMP) ignition system a "jet engine of progress" and claiming it brings "300 yard performance to muzzleloader season." This isn’t the first time Remington built a muzzleloader on the Model 700 action. In fact, the company was one of the first to bring a bolt-action inline to market with its Model 700 Muzzleloader in 1996. It was discontinued eight years later, probably because the heavily modified 700 action seemed to be more about aesthetics than any real advantage in performance. In the new Model 700 Ultimate Muzzleloader, Remington uses its short-action 700 receiver and a specialized breechplug to harness the ignition of a magnum rifle primer, which produces a longer, hotter flame than a 209 primer. The system reliably ignites up to four, 50-grain pellets of blackpowder substitute. No mistake: four pellets for a muzzle velocity just shy of 2400 fps with a saboted, .45-caliber bullet weighing 250 grains. That’s about 200 fps faster than a three-pellet load can do with the same bullet. It beats most .45-70 Gov’t loads and is on par with the .444 Marlin. For more information, check out the video embedded below, hosted by American Hunter Executive Editor Adam Heggenstaller, or go to Remington.com. Type: bolt-action inline muzzleloader Caliber: .50 Barrel: 6"; 1:26" twist; stainless steel; fluted Trigger: single-stage X-Mark Pro; adjustable; 6.1-lb. pull weight Sights: none on version tested; aperture rear and fiber-optic front on second version; both versions drilled and tapped for scope bases Safety: 2-position toggle Stock: Bell and Carlson composite with raised comb and beavertail fore-end (tested); LOP 14"; laminated wood Overall Length: 6" Weight: .5 lbs. Metal Finish: matte stainless steel Accessories: 20 pieces of primed brass; 20 bullets; aluminum ramrod with jag; polymer hard case MSRP: $1,295 For Further Reading: Remington's 300-Yard Muzzleloader
item.excerpt_encoded: Remington is touting its new Model 700 Ultimate Muzzleloader as a 300-yard muzzleloader.

item.title: Heckler & Koch VP9
item.creator: staff
item.excerpt_encoded: Heckler & Koch has released its newest striker-fired handgun, the VP9. Watch the video as Mark Keefe gets an exclusive first-look at the pistol, as well as chance to shoot it here at NRA Headquarters.

comment.comment_content: First striker fired HK? Umm, P7 and VP70, anyone?
First H&K striker fired weapon? Wasn't the P7 series striker fired?
H&K have long produced striker fired pistols. This is not the first one by a long shot.
Half my H&K pistols are striker-fired, already. Have we already forgotten the P7 series?

At the 5:20 minute or so of the video, it appears the shooter pulls the trigger, expecting the pistol to fire. It doesn't and the slide didn't lock back either. Just curious if other viewers noticed that and their thoughts.
Yes Jesse, I saw that. Must have malfunctioned. You would think that AR would have either edited that out or discussed the failure.

After watching the video again, you will see that it doesn't lock back after 15 rds fired in the intro @ 0:10. I'm wondering if this pistol doesn't lock open after an empty mag by design or malfunction?

Jesse, I didn't notice that at first because I wasn't really paying attention. I watched this video the way a fan of pickup trucks would watch a video about hybrid cars. The forums are already talking about this. Since the in-house expert didn't have a problem with it locking back, the most likely explanation is that Mark was inadvertently holding down the slide lock with his thumb. If you look at a picture of the VP9's left side, the slide lock has a very pronounced 'shelf' that would allow a thumb to engage it. Obviously he has a shooting style optimized for some other weapon, perhaps an M1911.

In the video, the slide drops on an empty chamber. The VP9 is designed to lock back on an empty chamber. While shooting for the video, I had a high grip on the gun with my thumb on top of the slide lock--too much M1911 shooting I guess--and my thump dropped the slide. I checked the gun again just to be sure, and, indeed it locks back on an empty chamber--provided you don't depress the slide lock.
Thanks Mark for reading the posts. Nice to know that readers' comments are not only read, but responded to as well. Thanks for clearing up this observation from the video!
Nice gun, but being an NRA Instructor, I don't like seeing a shooting team captain sweep himself multiple times while handling the gun.

No news video is bad news. Just received my American Rifleman Aug. 2014 Magazine on 7-22-14 and video is not available even at the H&K Web Site. No reason, no video. Featured article should have been honored. A lot of disappointed readers like me out there.

item.title: Ladies Choice
item.creator: clapp
item.content_encoded: This point came up in a gun counter discussion just last week: What is the most important consideration is helping a new female shooter select a handgun for personal defense? In my opinion, it is the size of her hand. Look at a woman’s hand as compared to a man’s. With some exceptions, her hand isn’t as wide, nor are the fingers as long. In order to shoot a new handgun well, she has to be able to get a positive grip. Most of the time, that means a sort of medium-sized pistol or revolver. I was in a Gunsite course a couple of years ago, where the class consisted of 16 shooters-eight men and eight women. Several of the ladies were professional law enforcement officers and handled their handguns with no small skill. Others were near neophytes and worked hard at learning the basics. I felt that two or three of the ladies would have been happier with and shoot better with slightly smaller pistols. If you are asked to contribute to the selection process for a particular woman, understand that there are several common mistakes to be avoided. Understanding that the woman’s hands are smaller, don’t go too far in choosing something that is little and fits the popular image of a woman’s gun. If a woman really wants a handgun, she knows her own mindset and wants all the gun that she can possibly handle. A too-small handgun may fit the hand and lifestyle of a particular woman, but it hurts to shoot and she won’t practice with it. Conversely, don’t pick out a handgun so big and powerful that only an NFL linebacker could manage it. This sometimes happens in the mistaken belief that if she needs a gun, she needs a monster. The important thing is matching the size of the gun to the hand. I have long felt that medium-frame revolvers (with proper grips) were a great choice, but revolvers seem to be falling from favor. Full-size semi-automatic pistols with double-column magazines tend to have thicker butt sections, which are not always compatible with short fingers. If she can’t get her hand around the pistol and fire several shots without losing her grip, the gun is not for her. Happily enough for those women in this category, the makers are beginning to offer single-column pistols of medium size that are ideal for this situation. If the lady in question can manage one of the short, double-stack pistols, so much the better. To re-iterate, match the size of the gun to the size of the hand.
item.excerpt_encoded: These days it seems everyone has an opinion about what exactly is the right gun for the beginner female handgunner. Wiley Clapp offers the most common-sense of answers.

comment.comment_content: I have a neighbor lady that has decided she needs a gun. She lives alone and has bad thoughts about somebody breaking into her home at night. I have volunteered to take her to the range and to the store for supplies and ammunition. But when it comes to suggesting a weapon, her small hands are only the tip of the iceberg. A 'gun' person would be thrilled with a new firearm and look forward to learning about it, giving it tender loving care, and replacing springs when needed if an auto. She is thinking more along the lines of something to put in the nightstand drawer and forget about until needed - perhaps in ten years. So not only does she need a weapon to fit her small hands, she needs a weapon to fit her small mindset. For her to have an auto would be a huge mistake; she can only have a revolver. So a .38 Special in a size that fits, soft rubber grips, as heavy as she is comfortable with, and a 4-inch barrel. But in the back of my mind there is a feeling that perhaps she will enjoy shooting it, actually think of it as something more important than a can opener, and start thinking that maybe she needs a little more power, you know, just in case. So let's make that a .357 Magnum and let her either stay with the Specials or grow into the Magnums. And maybe a longer barrel.

Yep, without a doubt, let the Lady decide on what she wants to shoot. She might surprise you!
Mr. Bigfoot - Seen many a post by you, kinda wonder why you are not writing some of these articles.
Woman's hands may be smaller overall but often times the palm has less meat. So many women's reach may be just as long or longer.<!--mobile-->
While any lady training at Gunsite is more likely to more of a gun person and in<!--mobile-->

While any lady training at Gunsite is more likely to be interested in mastering semiauto guns, but revolvers shouldn't be ignored. I've always found the original wood grips on S&W L frames and even some aftermarket rubber grips to be on the smaller size. I haven't shot any newer ones with rubber grips.
The non interest of mechanical things by some ladies makes the revolver a perfect weapon when it my set in a drawer for years. Of course training with a wheel gun is still desirable.<!--mobile-->

Contrary to the current philosophy of more is better, I’m personally, not a fan of double stack semi-autos for anyone who is not a gun enthusiast. First, unless the person, male or female, is going to practice and learn to clear jams and misfeeds, a semi-auto can cause more harm than good and put that person at increased risk. Second, in my opinion, and it’s just that, my opinion, the larger the ammo capacity, the greater the inclination to “Spray and pray” rather than shot placement. That, again, requires practice. Finally, how many rounds are needed to send an attacker [(]at home or out and about[)] fleeing or to stop an attack? 99 times out of a 100, it’s going to happen within the first 2 or 3 rounds or not at all.
After all my ramblings, it still comes down to matching the gun to the size of the hand and in my experience, with the ladies in my life, it has consistently ended up with a J frame or similar size revolver; simple and reliable.

item.title: 9 mm Revolver Bores
item.creator: clapp
item.content_encoded: A few years ago, I was deeply involved in persuading Smith & Wesson to build a particular model for the concealed-carry handgunners of this country. As many readers are aware, I am a big fan of the internal-hammer Centennial revolvers. I have been carrying them daily since the early ’70s and consider them to be the ideal concealed-carry handgun. Naturally, I was delighted when the company developed a light .357 Mag. Centennial, and I carry one of these every day. But, in a handgun world awash in 9 mm semi-autos, I felt-and still feel-that the company needed to offer a light 9 mm. Thus began a series of experiments to prove that this might be a good idea. The firm did offer a stainless steel 9 mm Centennial at this point in time, but it was too heavy to expect habitual carry by all but the most dedicated. I ran a series of chronograph tests comparing velocities of the same basic gun in 9 mm Luger and .38 Spl. If you kept bullet weights the same-124 to 125 grs. and 147 to 150 grs. in both cartridges, the results were surprising. The 9 mm gun turned in faster speeds than the .38 Spl. Since the company used the same basic platform for both calibers, the shorter 9 mm round had a lot of freebore in the cylinder. I assumed that the reason for the velocity disparity was the so-called “jump” in front of the cylinder. It may have been a contributory factor, but I am now convinced that there is another reason. I don’t believe the barrels on those early J-frame 9 mms were really 9 mms. I think they were .38 barrels marked 9 mm. The smaller 9 mm bullet was a looser fit in the larger bore and the velocity was therefore higher. And I also believe that this makes little difference in a short-range defensive handgun. A light 9 mm Centennial is still a good idea.
item.excerpt_encoded: A big fan of the Smith & Wesson Centennial revolvers-he carries one every day-Wiley Clapp thinks there needs to be a J-frame chambered in 9 mm Luger.

comment.comment_content:
http://www.charterfirearms.com/products/Charter_Pitbull_79920.asp
Charter arms already makes a 9mm revolver that does not need moon clips- pretty revolutionary
I still want a 4 shot 45 ACP J-Frame. Also I would love to see the 9mm with a shorted cylinder and overall frame shortened to match the 9mm.

What I'd really like to see them do, and I know they won't, would be to build one with a shorter cylinder and frame to accommodate the 9mm length, and either have a shorter gun, or extend the barrel to the same OA length as the other guns.
I would say a 9mm revolver would be a good build in a barrel lenght of 3 inch and bigger for accuracy since revolvers are very accurate in groupings <!--mobile-->
Lovely piece.<!--mobile-->
I'd buy one in a minute. <!--mobile-->
Not a big fan I f 9mm , what about a 40 9mm no moon clips similar to charter arms higher quality of course in S&W<!--mobile-->
A9mm revolver would be welcome for my use if it is compareable in size to my Solo<!--mobile-->

9mm has .357 Magnum pressures [(]35kpsi; +P is higher than .357 Mag[)], and therefore, will always post higher velocities than a .38 Special [(]17kpsi, 18.5kpsi +P[)]. The long powder column of the traditional revolver cartridges means you get very poor burn with powders which make them perform well out of 4'-or-longer barrels.
Ideally, a 9mm revolver should have a shorter cylinder and a recessed barrel coming into the cylinder window so that a J-frame of the same length can have a longer-than-normal barrel while still using regular holsters, etc.

I ran across a rather rare 10mm-chambered S&W revolver in a local pawn shop a while back. I should have bought it, since 10mm comes close to a .41 magnum in energy and rimless pistol cartridges are true dual-use [(]revolver and auto[)] rounds. To my knowledge at this time, only Taurus produces a 9mm Parabellum-chambered snubby revolver. S&W might be surprised at the sales they could generate were they to chamber a revolver in 9mm and even .40S&W; not only a snub-nose but also something in, say, a 4' barrel length. I'd certainly buy one. I hate chasing down brass that's ejected by an auto, for starters and revolvers will function no matter what sort of loads/bullets you put in them!

Smith and Wesson introduced two new 9mm revolvers early this year. Both are larger frame guns built mainly for competition. The cylinders are shorter in length for the shorter cartridge and the barrel have a true 9mm [(].355'[)] internal diameter. <!--mobile-->

Another meaningful article by Mr. Clapp. It is educational to get hard facts as opposed to just theory. To add to his article, consider the following ballistics from a Speer Reloading Manual where they fired Speer factory ammunition over their chronograph using 124/125 grain bullets in .38 Special, .357 Magnum, and 9mm. .38 Special: 2-inch barrel [(]976 fps[)]; 4-inch barrel [(]1148 fps[)]; 6-inch barrel [(]1160 fps[)]. .357 Magnum: 2 1/2-inch barrel [(]1223 fps[)]; 4-inch barrel [(]1388 fps[)]; 6-inch barrel [(]1495 fps[)]. 9mm: 4-inch barrel [(]1109 fps[)]. Prevailing wisdom states that the .38 Special is the minimum revolver cartridge to be used for self-defense and that the .357 enjoys an excellent reputation as a top-of-the-list 'stopper.' So, to move from minimum class to stopper class you simply add velocity to your 125-grain bullet. Another interesting observation is that a 2 1/2-inch .357 trumps a 6-inch .38. For those thinking about a house gun, notice the advantage of a longer barrel. Moving up from a 4-inch barrel to a 6-inch barrel in .357 provides you with an extra 100 fps of velocity, less blast, more control, and a longer sighting radius. And finally, the 800-pound gorilla in the room: If the .38 Special isn't so special, why is its ballistic twin, the 9mm, held in such high regard? After all, a 4-inch .38 Special 125-grain bullet produces 1148 fps and the 9mm 124-grain bullet produces 1109 fps. Even going to the 9mm+P, you only pick up around 70 fps.

I have one of the 940 Centennials that you are talking about, and I love it! It's accurate, the weigh at first was a concern, but if you shoot +P's in a small gun like that, the weight goes a long way to help the recoil. I think they should make them again, and like you say, in a lighter version.
I've been wanting one forever. <!--mobile-->
i must agree, I carry a S&W Centennial Model 940 9MM everyday

Taurus & Charter are in the 9mm revolver making business, seems S&W has some catching up to do. I did talk to an older woman at the range one day who said she was looking for one of the Charter 9mm revolvers [(]it was, I admit, the first I'd learned of it[)] and had feelers out, but her sources just had not been able to find her one, yet. @ David - S&W made the Model 547, a 9mm Parabellum, at one time, I believe with a 3' barrel, so blending that and the Centennial would be a nifty product. Ruger seems to be rather progressive with their LCR, maybe they would see fit to chamber it in 9mm?
It would be nice to only need a single caliber for my auto and my wife's revolver.

I have a S&W 547 and it does indeed have a heavy 3' barrel. I bought it used from a man who said it recoiled too much for him. I never considered myself recoil resistant, but I find it shoots nicely, even handles some Norinco ammo that doesn't fit some other 9 mm guns I have. It holds six cartridges. I have heard several tales about why it appeared and disappeared from S&W's line up, including that it was a special run for the Israelis so they would have a revolver that used the same ammo as the Uzi. That doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but adds a certain mystique to the gun.
The 9mm case undoubtedly provides for more reliable ejection in a short barreled [(]and short ejector rod[)] revolver.<!--mobile-->

item.title: Snap Shots: Rockin’ the Duck Pond and the “Backward N” Brander
item.creator: keefe
item.content_encoded: We have a winner for “Not What Wilbur & Orville Had in Mind … and Bacon.” Donald Nix Facebook submitted: “Young Si and Phil Robertson test Si's latest invention, a flying duck blind/rotisserie.” You, sir, have earned yourself a can of Tactical Bacon. And speaking of the Robertsons … When you have magazines dating back to 1885, you end up flipping through pages and chuckling at times over what you find. Although American Rifleman is the world's oldest and largest firearms authority, it doesn’t mean we can’t have a little fun. And we’re willing to share that fun with our readers. Here’s a gem from our predecessor Arms & The Man. That’s right before shotguns and duck calls, duck hunting was, uh, a rocky proposition. And it appears our pre-gunpowder friend here is not a pre-Robertson as he has an appalling lack of facial hair. Curiously, he apparently is attired in a faux goatskin seat cover that eventually made it onto the driver’s seat of an editor’s 1977 Datsun. Keep it clean. Bloomberg probably pays an intern minimum wage to read this blog. Entries will be subjectively judged by staff editors between takes of the TV show, testing guns and making authors seem literate. The winner and others we deem worthy will be printed here. All judgements final. No returns. Winner will receive a random item from a box under Mark Keefe's desk the manufacturer did not want back, yet was marginally valuable enough to not throw away. This week, we have a special treat, snared from the very abyss of the HQ dumpster. What with it being summertime and all, a time to grill steak and sweet corn, we thought it the ideal time for the flawed NRA steak branding iron. We call it the limited-edition “Backward N” NRA brander. Frankly, we probably don’t BBQ enough, because until this baby came into our possession, we didn’t even know you could brand your steaks. Object is unused-not clean-but unused. Handle is of porous wood, really unfinished, and it comes complete with leather thong. A 10-inch steel shaft terminates in a head emblazoned with the letters “NRA”-although the “N” is, indeed, backward. We think we may have lost a marketing buyer over this one. Device not approved for use on corn. Official Snapshots Rules: • Caption submissions must be made in the comments section of this blog, or on the corresponding Facebook post. • One winner will be chosen, selected by Mark Keefe or a randomly selected guest judge. • Keep it clean, folks.
item.excerpt_encoded: Week five of snapshots is here! That’s right, before shotguns and duck calls, duck hunting was, uh, a rocky proposition. Write the best caption and you could win a prize that will make all your friends jealous.
