item.title: PA State Police Select SIG Sauer P227 as Next Service Firearm
item.creator: staff
item.content_encoded: After extensive testing of several .45-caliber handguns from a number of manufacturers, the Pennsylvania State Police has selected the SIG Sauer P227 as the agency’s next service firearm. The contract calls for more than 5,000 pistols to be delivered before the end of 2014. “For decades, the Classic series handguns have been a dependable partner to tens of thousands of law enforcement officers,” said Tom Jankiewicz, Executive Director, Law Enforcement Sales for SIG Sauer, Inc. “The P227 continues that legacy with its combination of greater capacity and larger caliber.” The Pennsylvania State Police is the primary law enforcement agency for approximately 81 percent of the land mass and 25 percent of the population of the Commonwealth and currently employs 4,719 troopers. The agency’s new P227 pistols are being issued to the current class of State Police Cadets at the State Patrol Academy in Hershey and will be distributed to all Troopers across the state by the end of the year. For more information, visit SIG Sauer.
item.excerpt_encoded: The contract calls for more than 5,000 pistols to be delivered before the end of 2014.

item.title: Official Beretta Press Release
item.creator: staff
item.content_encoded: For Immediate Release:  July 22, 2014 BERETTA U.S.A. ANNOUNCES DECISION TO MOVE ITS ENTIRE MARYLAND MANUFACTURING CAPABILITIES TO TENNESSEE Beretta U.S.A. Corp., located in Accokeek, Maryland, announced today that it has decided to move its manufacturing capabilities from its existing location to a new production facility that it is building in Gallatin, Tennessee.  The Gallatin facility is scheduled to be opened in mid-2015.  Beretta U.S.A. had previously planned to use the new Gallatin, Tennessee facility for new machinery and production of new products only. “During the legislative session in Maryland that resulted in passage of the Firearm Safety Act of 2013, the version of the statute that passed the Maryland Senate would have prohibited Beretta U.S.A. from being able to manufacture, store or even import into the State products that we sell to customers throughout the United States and around the world.  While we were able in the Maryland House of Delegates to reverse some of those obstructive provisions, the possibility that such restrictions might be reinstated in the future leaves us very worried about the wisdom of maintaining a firearm manufacturing factory in the State,” stated Jeff Cooper, General Manager for Beretta U.S.A. Corp. “While we had originally planned to use the Tennessee facility for new equipment and for production of new product lines only, we have decided that it is more prudent from the point of view of our future welfare to move the Maryland production lines in their entirety to the new Tennessee facility,” Cooper added. The transition of production from Beretta U.S.A.’s Maryland facility to the Tennessee facility will not occur until 2015 and will be managed so as not to disrupt deliveries to Beretta customers.  Beretta U.S.A.’s production of the U.S. Armed Forces M9 9mm pistol will continue at the Accokeek, Maryland facility until all current orders from the U.S. Armed Forces have been filled. “We have not yet begun groundbreaking on the Tennessee facility and we do not anticipate that that building will be completed until the middle part of 2015,” continued Cooper.  “That timing, combined with our need to plan an orderly transition of production from one facility to the other so that our delivery obligations to customers are not disrupted, means that no Beretta U.S.A. Maryland employee will be impacted by this news for many months.  More importantly, we will use this time to meet with every Beretta U.S.A. employee whose Maryland job might be affected by the move to discuss with them their interest in taking a position at our new facility in Tennessee or, if they are not willing to do so, to lay out a long-term strategy for remaining with the Company while our production in Maryland continues.” Beretta U.S.A. anticipates that the Gallatin, Tennessee facility will involve $45 million of investment in building and equipment and the employment of around 300 employees during the next five years. Beretta U.S.A. has no plans to relocate its office, administrative and executive support functions from its Accokeek, Maryland facility. About Beretta Beretta, established in 1526, is the oldest industrial dynasty in the world tracing its roots through 16 generations of continuous family ownership. Firearms bearing the Beretta name have been sold for almost 500 years.  Beretta USA Corp. was founded in 1977 and supplies the standard sidearm to the U.S. Armed Forces.  Today, Beretta manufactures, distributes and markets a complete line of firearms, accessories and apparel.  Beretta also owns and operates six retail Beretta Gallery stores worldwide. For additional information, visit www.beretta.com.
item.excerpt_encoded: Read the official BerettaUSA announcement in its entirely regarding its decision to move its entire Maryland manufacturing capabilities to Tennessee.

item.title: Tac-Con 3MR Trigger
item.creator: keefe
item.content_encoded: There is a host of aftermarket triggers available for the AR platform, but the drop-in unit from Tactical Fire Control offers not only a crisp single-stage trigger pull but adds a “third mode” of operation. Typically, semi-automatic ARs have two positions, “safe” and “fire,” and the Tac-Con, of course, has both. The standard “fire” position delivers a conventional, consistent 4-lb., 9-oz. pull. But the 3MR, which comes with its own selector lever, adds a position 180 degrees from safe (where selective-fire would be on an M16) for its proprietary third mode. Movement of the bolt carrier against a lever on the rear of unit drives the trigger blade positively forward, providing a pull that measured 4 lbs., 7 ozs., in my DPMS AP4 with virtually no takeup and little overtravel. You can actually see and feel the trigger blade, which is raked more forward than standard AR triggers, coming forward as the bolt carrier moves when set in the third mode. The self-contained unit, made of EDM or CNC-machined steel coated in NP3 nickel Teflon, behaves like a short-reset trigger for AR-type rifles. Installation is quick and easy, and your rifle’s original trigger pins can be used. Even though it has three-positions, the unit is semi-automatic only, and is priced at $495. Contact: Tactical Fire Control, Inc. 44047 N. 43rd Avenue, Phoenix, AZ 85087 (623) 282-1881
item.excerpt_encoded: The drop-in unit from Tactical Fire Control offers not only a crisp single-stage trigger pull but adds a “third mode” of operation.

comment.comment_content: Tried the 3MR trigger in my JR Carbine[(]9mm[)] would not reset. Single shot only. Sent lower to Tac-Con they said it worked in their guns. Sent it back tried again Still Single shot. no reset. Had to manually recharge. Sent it back for refund. Tac_Con tried and were quick on the refuned.

item.title: Gerber Cortex Flashlights
item.creator: staff
item.content_encoded: Settling a common resupply quandary for outdoorsmen and tactical users, Gerber designed its Cortex flashlight to operate on either two AA or three CR123 batteries. Likewise, its Cortex Compact uses either one AA or one CR123. The U.S.-assembled lights have machined 6061-T6 aluminum housings and Cree white LEDs activated by rubberized tailcap switches with momentary and click-on, click-off settings for high, low and strobe modes. The Cortex is 6.3" long and weighs 5.8 ozs. While the Cortex Compact is 3.5"-4" long, depending on battery, and weighs 2.1 ozs. Both lights include replaceable spring-steel pocket clips and come with AA batteries. Price: $104 (Cortex) $82 (Cortex Compact) Contact: Gerber Gear, 14200 S.W. 72nd Ave., Portland, OR 97224 (855) 544-0150
item.excerpt_encoded: Gerber designed its Cortex flashlight to operate on either two AA or three CR123 batteries.

item.title: Going Viking: Pistol Bayonets and a Pistol Axe!
item.creator: keefe
item.content_encoded: We recently gave away a pistol bayonet from LaserLyte as a prize for our "Snap Shots" caption contest. This, of course raised some questions about pistol bayonets. Coincidently, NRA's National Firearms Museum received-on loan-an original Elgin Cutlass pistol as well as a wheel-lock pistol with an axe blade. A pretty wicked looking one, too. The concept of putting a blade on a handgun is not new. Early in the development of firearms, it was not necessarily clear which was the superior defensive arm, the wheel-lock single-shot pistol or the sword. Or in the all-steel example shown here, axes. The earliest hand firearms combined with blades in the 16th century would be more rightly swords or daggers with guns attached, but these were permanently affixed. For long guns, adding a blade to a musket converted it into a pike. The bayonet, in plug form, itself wasn’t recorded until 1571 according to Rodolphe Schmidt’s Les Arms a Feu Portatives. Schmidt dates the detachable bayonet to 1641-42. In handguns, the English maker John Waters of Birmingham was granted a patent in 1781 for “Pistols with a Bayonet” for single-shot flintlock pistols and they could be “connected by a spring, slide, hinge or otherwise.” Commonly the blade was hinged at the front and then swung forward upon being released, much like a Chinese SKS bayonet. These were generally pocket guns carried with the spike folded until needed. The efficacy of the single-shot pistol was theoretically enhanced by the inclusion of such a device. George Elgin gets the credit for the first major American handgun/blade device patented in 1837 for “a new and useful instrument called the Pistol-Knife or Pistol-Cutlass,” and it emerged during the young nation’s fascination of Bowie knives. The single-shot Elgin Cutlass Pistol was made by Morrill, Mosman and Blair of Amherst, Mass., and by C.B. Allen of Springfield, Mass. The latter is said to have used blades fabricated by another famous Massachusetts firm, the Ames Mfg. Co. The U.S. Navy procured 150 of the .54 cal. single-shot version with 11” blades for South Sea Exploring Expedition. This was, interestingly, the first U.S. issue percussion handgun. Colt, too, dabbled with the idea of a cutlass revolver, reportedly in 1836-the same year Samuel Colt received his revolving cylinder patent-with a knuckle guard, straight blade, and interestingly, a bobbed hammer and double-action mechanism. In Lewis Wainant’s Firearms Curiosa, a photo depicts renowned collector Charles Noe Daly wearing a cuirass with 19 pistols and holding what appears to be a pinfire of the Lefacheaux pattern, again with a wicked-looking Bowie-style blade. The pistol bayonet had a rebirth in the trenches the World War I with the Webley-Pritchard bayonet attachment fitted to the Webley Mk VI revolver, often in concert with a detachable shoulder stock (remember the mace even made a comeback in the close quarters of the trenches). The triangular Webley-Pritchard, fashioned from cut-down French Gras bayonets, was made by W.W. Greener and slid over the front of the revolver. International Military Antiques has been offering reproductions with the scabbard and frog, and its reproduction has far outstripped the original manufacture run. As rapidity of loading increased the effectiveness of the handgun sans bayonet, such devices fell into the seldom seen novelty category. The introduction of a standardized Picatinny open rail on the front dustcover of many of today’s handguns opened the door for all manner of accessories to be mounted, primarily lights and lasers, but it also facilitated the addition of an under-barrel bayonet. In 2005 Ceska Zbrovka (CZ) reintroduced the concept on the CZ-75 based Model 01 handgun. According to CZ USA’s Jason Morton, the blade was an afterthought. The concept was to mount an impact device for glass breakage and to allow the pistol to operate with muzzle contact (depressing the slide front moves the pistol out of battery) on a surface, organic or otherwise. It took the form of an underside rail with a false muzzle that could attach to the dustcover. When the concept was sent to the firm’s engineers in the Czech Republic, they added a removable blade. In more recent years, Laserlyte updated the concept with a pistol bayonet that feature a 2¾” Ka-Bar serrated blade mounted in a nylon-reinforced polymer handle that makes the “instrument” look like a modern military bayonet in miniature. Retention is via two latches at the top rear. More recently, Laserlyte has added the Mini Tac Tool that has a squared, serrated and beveled blade that has a web cutter on its top surface. The ability to rapidly reload modern handguns has greatly diminished whatever practicality existed for such device in close combat. Several accomplished defensive trainers suggested a fixed bladed knife is preferable to an unloaded pistol with a bayonet affixed. Regardless of their utility in a close-quarters situation (a fixed bladed knife would likely be more useful), they are undoubtably interesting.
item.excerpt_encoded: Okay, thanks to LaserLyte, most of us have seen a pistol bayonet, and here is a brief history of the dubious devices. But a pistol axe? Seriously? Don't make us go all viking on you.

item.title: NASCAR's No. 3 Highlights NRA National Sporting Arms Museum
item.creator: Justin_McDaniel
item.content_encoded: When NASCAR Sprint Cup Series rookie Austin Dillon takes to the high banks of Daytona International Speedway under the lights for the Coke Zero 400 on July 5, he’ll certainly have history on his side-literally, and in more ways than one. Thanks to primary sponsor Bass Pro Shops and its founder, Johnny Morris, Dillon’s red, white and blue Chevrolet will feature a special paint scheme highlighting the new NRA National Sporting Arms Museum. The museum, which traces the evolution of hunting and conservation from the 1600s to the present through its collection of firearms, artifacts and dioramas, will be prominently displayed on the rear quarter panels, deck lid and back of Dillon’s Chevy SS. The sponsorship is particularly fitting considering that Dillon himself is a lifelong hunter and shooter, as is his car owner and grandfather, NRA Board member Richard Childress. “The car we’ll have in Daytona supports the NRA museum that was just built and opened up by Johnny Morris, a great man, friend and supporter of our race team at Richard Childress Racing,” said Childress, who serves as chairman of the NRA Hunting and Wildlife Conservation Committee. “He and I both feel very strongly about the NRA and what its goals are for educating people about guns, conservation and hunting.” A powerful advocate for hunters, Childress recognized the importance of gun safety, wildlife conservation and our Second Amendment freedoms at an early age. They are values he has devoted considerable time to promoting and protecting-and passing on to his grandsons. “I’ve been hunting, shooting and enjoying the outdoors with my family my entire life,” said Dillon. “It’s part of our livelihoods, and it’s what we do together as a family to relax away from the racetrack. The NRA National Sporting Arms Museum focuses on hunting, conservation and freedom. I can’t think of anything more American than that, so I’m really excited about the race weekend and highlighting firearms freedom.” If representing those freedoms and all they stand for wasn’t weighty enough for the 24-year-old, Dillon will also be carrying on the tradition of the legendary No. 3 car at Daytona. Made famous by the late Dale Earnhardt, the No. 3 had been unofficially retired from Sprint Cup Series competition since the seven-time champion was killed on the final lap of the 2001 Daytona 500. Earnhardt visited victory lane at Daytona a record 34 times, with the vast majority of those wins coming while driving the No. 3 car. Childress, whose cars Earnhardt piloted to six of his seven series championships, as well as his victory in the 1998 Daytona 500, brought the No. 3 out of retirement for the start of the 2014 season. “All of us at Bass Pro Shops are proud to partner with our good friend and conservationist Richard Childress and his grandson Austin Dillon by paying tribute to the NRA and the new National Sporting Arms Museum, which is located at Bass Pro Shops’ flagship superstore in Springfield, Mo., by donating a special NRA paint scheme,” said Morris. “We couldn’t think of a better way to salute the NRA membership and museum than to feature it on the famous No. 3 Chevy when it returns to Daytona on the Fourth of July weekend.” This is not the first time Bass Pro Shops has promoted the NRA through its NASCAR sponsorships. In fact, the outdoor retail giant has donated special NRA-themed paint schemes on six prior occasions, including on cars driven by Ryan Newman and Jamie McMurray in the 2011 and 2012 summer races at Daytona, respectively. “Johnny Morris and everyone at Bass Pro Shops are true friends of the National Rifle Association,” said NRA Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre. “Johnny has always been a staunch supporter of our hunting and shooting heritage, and it was through his vision and generosity that we were able to build the NRA National Sporting Arms Museum. We are honored that Bass Pro Shops has chosen to use its sponsorship of the No. 3 car to highlight the new museum, and there’s no better backdrop than Daytona on Independence Day weekend.” A decade in the making, the idea behind the museum took hold when Morris visited the NRA National Firearms Museum at NRA Headquarters in Fairfax, Va. Inspired by the collection, Morris wanted to bring the artistry and history of sporting arms to the heartland where millions more Americans could enjoy it-a vision NRA readily embraced. With a commitment to sharing sporting arms history, Bass Pro Shops donated the space for the museum in its Springfield store and provided the funding to design and build the 7,500-sq.-ft. museum, while NRA provided the firearms and storylines for the exhibits. Since its doors opened in August 2013, nearly 300,000 people have visited the new museum, which houses a collection of more than 1,000 firearms that tell the story of America’s hunting and shooting heritage. Notable pieces in the collection include a flintlock fowler once owned by England’s King James II that dates to the 1600s; a Girandoni air rifle as used by Lewis and Clark on their journey to the Pacific and back between 1804 and 1806; President Grover Cleveland’s 8-gauge side-by-side Colt shotgun, the only known 8-gauge Colt ever made; the Winchester Model 21 shotgun presented to President Dwight D. Eisenhower by Robert Woodruff, president of Coca-Cola; a Holland & Holland .700 NE double rifle, the largest double rifle ever made by the venerable firm; and the Shiloh Sharps rifle used by NRA Board member Tom Selleck in his role as Matthew Quigley in the 1990 film “Quigley Down Under.” Visitors can see these guns and many more historically significant firearms in the museum’s one-of-a-kind collection by visiting the Bass Pro Shops retail outlet in Springfield, Mo., which is located at 1935 S. Campbell Ave. The museum is open every day from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. and admission is free. Dillon and the Bass Pro Shops/NRA Museum No. 3 will take the green flag for the Coke Zero 400 at 7:30 p.m. ET on Saturday, July 5. The race will be televised on TNT.
item.excerpt_encoded: Austin Dillon and the Bass Pro Shops/NRA Museum No. 3 will take the green flag for the Coke Zero 400 on Sat., July 5, 2014.

item.title: SIG Elite Performance Brings New Ammo Source to Market
item.creator: John Zent
item.content_encoded: If nothing else, SIG Sauer’s Elite Performance ammunition will be a welcome new source for a commodity that’s been too hard to get for too long. I’m betting it goes further than that. If this new ammo line makes an nth of the market impact as SIG firearms, the result will be enthused shooters and a handsome return on investment. Leave it to the free-enterprise system to come to the rescue. SIG is betting, too, that its gold-star reputation will attract a customer base that appreciates the elite accuracy and stopping power widely associated with its name. However, unlike firms that seek to leverage a successful brand by using it to cross-market related products, SIG isn’t just sticking its headstamp on cartridges loaded by some OEM supplier. Rather, the company went out and acquired a factory in Eubanks, Ky., where all the workers are now SIG employees. Clearly, this is a long-term commitment. The initial offerings span today’s most popular personal-defense handgun loadings: .380 Auto/90 grs.; 9 mm Luger/124 grs.; .357 SIG/125 grs.; .40 S&W/165 grs.; and .45 Auto/200 grs. The cartridge brass is coated with “Techni-crom,” which SIG says increases lubricity to ensure fail-safe feeding and extraction. The key component is the proprietary V-Crown bullet, a hollow-point with a dual cavity design. Its cone-shaped nose depression extends to a long, thin channel into the core.  According to SIG, this design produces, “ ... controlled, uniform expansion at all effective distances and velocities.” We’re going to rely on ace ammo-performance analyst Richard Mann to provide a full T&E on Elite Performance ammunition in an upcoming American Rifleman article, but I can report being duly impressed during my own initial range session. We fired the 9 mm load in a Hi-Point carbine and it held 2” groups from sandbags at 50 yards. That gun has chronic extraction problems, but not so with the Elite Performance, which fed and ejected flawlessly. The same was true with two boxes of .45 Auto rounds we put through a brand-new M1911, and the accuracy at 15 yards was equally satisfying.
item.excerpt_encoded: SIG is now making its own branded ammo in a company-owned U.S. plant.

Thanks for reading everyone. As we expected there's ample interest in the new SIG ammo, and along with that some questions. Regarding where to get it, the best bet is to consult the Dealer Locator on SIG's website -https://www.sigsauer.com/DealerLocator/Default.aspx. There you will find several national chains, most of which are listing the new ammo on their websites. You can also find your local dealers, and folks from the company say those identified as 'Premium SIGnificant' dealers are carrying the new ammo line. SIG says more calibers will be added, including rifle cartridges, but we have no further details on that. American Rifleman magazine will produce a full report with ballistics and bullet performance testing in an upcoming issue, and naturally those results will be shared on this website as well.

item.title: Stag Arms Model 3G
item.creator: staff
item.content_encoded: When the Team Stag Arms 3-Gun shooting was formed a few years ago, the manufacturer decided to produce a rifle that had the broadest appeal for this specific competition. What they came up with is the Stag Arms Model 3G. The rifle features an 18″ stainless-steel, fluted heavy barrel with a rifle length gas system. The Stag Arms Super 3Gun compensator reduces recoil impulse, allowing for fast follow up shots. Aiding in accuracy is the Samson Evolution handguard, which is free floating and modular, allowing the attachment of rail sections or sling mounts along the handguard. This also grants the shooter the ability to mount accessories as needed but not be burdened with a full quad rail. The trigger is a Geissele Super 3-Gun trigger, developed specifically for 3-Gun competitions. The buttstock and pistol grip are from Magpul, featuring its collapsible ACS buttstock. The rifle also is available with optional Dueck Defense Rapid Transition Sights (RTS) which are offset iron sights that are used for close in shots. And although the rifle was designed for  3-Gun competitors, its appeal is not limited to this group. The rifle can and will appeal to anyone looking for an accurate, reliable, and modular AR-15 rifle. MSRP: $1,459 MSRP with Dueck Defense RTS: $1,659 For more on our latest Gun of the Week, watch the video below, hosted by American Rifleman's Joe Kurtenbach: Technical Specifications: 18-inch stainless steel fluted heavy barrel with a rifle length gas system, 5.56 NATO chamber, and 1/8 twist rate. Stag Arms Super 3Gun Comp Samson 15-inch Evolution free-float modular handguard with three rail attachments included. Geissele Super 3 Gun (S3G) trigger Magpul ACS buttstock and MOE pistol grip. Optional Dueck Defense Rapid Transition Sights (RTS) Further Reading: Stag Arms Model 3G & 3GL 3-Gun Competition Rifle
item.excerpt_encoded: Designed for 3-Gun competition, this rifle is so versatile its appeal is not limited to competitive shooters.

item.title: Top Five All-Around Sporting Cartridges
item.creator: DaveCampbell
item.content_encoded: Aficionados of sporting rifles detest the notion of one rifle that can do virtually everything. We love rifles, and the more, the better. But there are those who cannot afford or don’t want a gaggle of rifles to take care of. They value simplicity and versatility, and often they like to say, “Beware the man with one gun. He probably knows how to use it.” Here’s a look at five of the most popular all-around cartridges with some mentions of their not-so-popular ballistic twins. The .30-06 Springfield The 108-year-old .30-06 Sprg. is without a doubt the king of all-around cartridges. It has been chambered in every rifle action ever designed, from single-shot to semi-automatic-even machine guns. Of military heritage, the .30-06 was the culmination of an effort to outdo the 7x57 mm Mauser that stung U.S. troops so badly during the Spanish-American War. The initial offspring-the .30-03-featured a 220-gr. round-nose bullet at 2400 fps. It had thump but not range. Three years later came the .30-06 with a 150-gr. bullet at 2900 f.p.s. Two world wars plus the Korean conflict gave several generations of soldiers and hunters a decisive performance record for the cartridge. In short, it works very well on varmints up through big game. With 110- to 125-gr. bullets at 3200 f.p.s the .30-06 Sprg will hold its own against .22- and .24-cal. varmint rigs. Sure the dedicated varminter will perform better, especially at long range, but Mr. One Rifle won’t need to pack up his gear and wait in the truck. The 150- to 180-grainers is where this cartridge shines, and as long as you choose your bullets wisely and do your part as a shooter, the .30-06 Sprg. will handle any deer, antelope, elk or moose you care to tangle with. Bullets from 200 to 250 grains in the .30 caliber will thump hard-on both ends-but they’ll also get the job done. Longtime friend and rifle scribe Sam Fadala took a Cape buffalo with a 220-gr., .30-06, and he did so with just one shot. The .30-06 Sprg. has been necked down to .22 caliber and necked up to .400. Ballistic twins-in terms of practicality-the .270 Win. and .280 Rem. can do just about what their pappy can. The .270 shoots a bit flatter, as does the .280, but I rather doubt there is a creature on earth that could tell the difference once hit with any of these cartridges. 7 mm Remington Magnum Introduced 52 years ago along with the Remington 700 rifle, the 7 mm Rem. Mag. has muscled itself into the all-around cartridge tribe. The intention was to provide a cartridge that shoots flatter and hits harder than the .30-06 Sprg. and still keep recoil manageable. Bullet weights for handloaders range from the 110-grain Barnes TTSX to 190-grain Bergers. With a Barnes 110-gr. TTSX loaded to 3500 fps you can keep the marmots at bay. The 140- to 190-gr. at from 2860 to 3110 f.p.s. are the bread-and-butter bullets for most American big-game hunters. Deer, pronghorn, elk and moose are all fair game for Big Green’s Big 7. In order to achieve those ballistics, however, the 7 mm Rem. Mag. needs a long enough barrel-26” or even 28”. Shorter and more common 24” barrels give up enough velocity and make the Big 7 a sort of loud .270 Win. on a belted case. Usually the sophisticated 7 mm Mag shooter has a custom rifle made with a longer barrel to take full advantage of the cartridge and its capabilities. Many 7 mm Mag aficionados prefer it because it provides true magnum performance with less recoil that the .300 Win. Mag. Attempts have been made to “magnum” the 7 mm Remington Magnum-most notably the 7 mm STW and 7 mm Remington Ultra Mag-but none have been able to unseat the Big 7 from its perch as one of the great and most popular all-around cartridges. For the hair splitters, the .30 calibers tend to be slightly more accurate than the 7 mm because more effort has been put forth-especially via target shooters-to make more accurate bullets. That said, there are some custom 7s out there that can shoot rings around most of the .30s. .300 Win. Mag. Though neither the first .30-cal. magnum, nor the most powerful one, the .300 Win. Mag. has earned a place in the hearts of many big-game hunters worldwide. Like its older brothers-the .264, .338 and .458 Winchester Magnums-the .300 Win. is one of the first short magnums. All three cartridges came from the .375 H&H Mag. shortened so that they would fit in a standard .30-06-Sprg.-length bolt-action rifle. It offers about 9 percent more velocity than the .30-06 but nearly 30 percent more energy at the muzzle. The .300 Win. Mag. quickly garnered a reputation as a fine deer and elk cartridge, especially out in the west where shots tend to be longer. Initially it also had a reputation as a hard-kicking and difficult to handle rifle. However, once shooters demanded a better stock design with a straight comb and little drop at the heel and they learned how to control it, the .300 Win. Mag.’s popularity soared. It is now one of the go-to cartridges for long-range sniping and 1,000-yard target shooting in addition to its longtime popularity with hunters. It is a top choice for plains game in Africa and a great choice for bear, whether black, brown or grizzly. It gets some grief from handloaders because of its short neck, but most hunters don’t mind because of its performance in the field. Ballistic theoreticians dissed the short neck as an impediment for accuracy, but, again, the fact that the .300 Win. Mag. delivers the goods for long-range hunters, snipers and on the target range pretty well dismisses that argument. .375 Holland & Holland Magnum There may not be quite as many .375 H&H Magnums lounging in the racks of pickup trucks as there are .30-06s, but worldwide the cartridge remains one of the most popular ones of all time-and rightly so. Its trajectory is as flat as a .30-06, but it delivers 40 percent more energy to the target. That might not seem so big a deal if all you are shooting are antelope and deer, but if the target can either bite or stomp you back that increase in energy can be a lifesaver. The .375 H&H Mag. is usually loaded with bullets from 200 to 300 grains, with the 235- to 270-grainers most popular. As with all of these cartridges, ammunition is usually available anywhere in the world where it is sold. In terms of need, unless you are hunting one of the larger bears-grizz or brown-the .375 H&H Mag. isn’t really needed. However, when one’s hunting adventures take them abroad and big cats or buffalo are on the menu most hunters want all the edge they can get. The .375 is one of the most popular stopper or backup rifles used by guides and professional hunters. In rifles with well-designed stocks recoil-which many have reported as vicious in order to puff up their own egos-is quite manageable. I would probably not want to spend a day shooting prairie dogs with a .375, nor would I want a .223 Rem. in my hands if facing a Cape buffalo. On my first safari I took only a .375 and used it on everything from 140-lb. impalas to a 2,000-lb. eland. I’d call that an all-around cartridge. Winchester Center Fire (WCF) To round out our top five all-around sporting cartridges I chose one that has been more than just popular for 119 years. This cartridge was initially in a lever-action rifle and remains virtually synonymous with that rifle platform. Yet it, too, has been chambered in bolt actions, single shots and even drillings. A rimless version-the .30 Remington-has seen service in pump and semi-automatic rifles as well. Like the other cartridges examined here, it has been used worldwide from rabbits to elephants and pretty much everything in between. I am referring, of course, to the .30-30 Winchester Center Fire (WCF). Often cited as the first smokeless powder cartridge, the .30-30 was actually predated a few months by its smaller sibling the .25-35 WCF. But the .30 caliber outshone the older sibling in spades. More than 7 million Model 94 Winchester rifles have been made, and the vast majority were chambered in .30-30. Other lever actions such as the Savage 99 and Mossberg’s Model 464, have been chambered for this round. Savage also made a couple of bolt actions in .30-30, the models 325 and 340. The cartridge has been used for everything from bunnies to moose and walrus. Though sniffed at and disdained by many modern riflemen, the .30-30 is still plenty of gun for most big game when used within its 200 yard limitation. I have a cast-bullet load featuring the RCBS 150-gr. flat point in front of 15 grains of IMR Trail Boss that will consistently take the eye out of a cottontail at 25 yards. Noise and recoil is nil. So there you have it; my five top all-around sporting cartridges. As a collector and user of rifles I’d hate to be limited to just one. But for those who prefer to be the one-gun man, any of these cartridges would serve you very well.
item.excerpt_encoded: Dave Campbell offers a look at the most popular all-around sporting cartridges.

comment.comment_content: I have three of your cartridges, the .30-30, the .30-06, and the .300 Winchester Magnum. The .30-30 would never make it as my 'All-Around Rifle.' While it is a joy to carry and shoot, it is just too ballistically challenged compared to the other two. I grew up with the .30-06, taking antelope, deer, and elk with it. And while it did everything I asked of it, there just wasn't anything special about it. Sorry, but life is too short to drink cheap Scotch and shoot plain-vanilla cartridges. As I went through the process of deciding what caliber would replace the .30-06 I came up with two alternatives. I could get a .270 Winchester for deer and antelope AND a .338 Winchester Magnum for elk and moose OR I could compromise with the .300 Winchester Magnum. I opted for the .300. Being a handloader I took advantage of the long Remington 700 action and magazine by loading my rounds long, making room for maximum loads. I was able to safely get the 180-grain Sierra up to 3135 fps and the 180-grain Nosler Partition up to 3150 fps. Accuracy has been outstanding with both, always under one inch at 100 yards. The Sierra, at that velocity, sometimes comes unglued and makes for spectacular kills on deer and antelope. The Nosler is just perfect on the big stuff. America has always been in love with the 30 caliber cartridges and the big Winchester has earned its place as America's Top All-Around Cartridge.
30-06 all the way.
No 308 eh? I'd bet there are more 308s out there than 7mm and 375s put together. <!--mobile-->
I took my Alaska Brown Bear, Grizzly, with 180 grain, 30-06 at 300 yards. I love hunting with my -06.
My one gun has always been the 30.06 I can hunt ground hog in the morning and deer in the afternoon it just works ...<!--mobile-->

Most popular? According to who? For starters I have personally never met anyone who actually shoots a 375 H&H, how did this caliber even make it into this 'most popular' list?? And where is the 270 and 243 Winchester? According to Federal Ammunition 2011 sales figures, below are the most popular rifle calibers: 1. 30-06 Spr 2. .223 Rem 3. 30-30 Win 4. 308 Win 5. 270 Win 6. 7mm RemMag 7. .243 Win 8. 22-250 Rem 9. 300 WinMag 10. 25-06 Rem
According to RCBS, the most popular dies sold per volume for 2011 were: Rifle: 1. .308 Win 2. .223 Rem 3. 30-06 Spr 4. .243 Win 5. .270 Win 6 . .300 WinMag 7. 7mm RemMag 8. .22-250 Rem 9 7mm-08 Rem 10. .300 WSM
So the figures do not add up to the author's claims of 'most popular'. Please be factual in your articles and leave wishful thinking and flights of fancy for other discussions.
Thanks
I agree with your assessment. All are legendary cartridges. And of course 30-06 gets top billing. There is just nothing so versatile as 30-06.

It's always hard to pick the best when there are so many great cartridges. I have the '06, .300 WM and 30/30 and have taken big game with all three, the most with the '06. All work well when properly chosen for the job at hand. I kind of agree the .375 is a bit less of a 'popularity choice' but certainly performs. I too would have chosen the .270 Win. given it's popularity and track record. I have killed a lot of deer. antelope and a few elk with it. Never failed to do the job cleanly. As to the short neck on the .300 WM, mine shoots every load, light, heavy and match into one half inch with strong velocities. What more could I ask for? Finally, the .243 Win. is a great choice for deer, antelope and varmints. Thanks for the article.

I've owned and hunted with all of these except the .375 H&H. Can't argue with any of the selections but would add the .308 Win. somewhere. My favorite all around is the 7mm Rem. Mag. which I have used for whitetail and mule deer, and elk. For a worldwide cartridge, I've chosen the .416 Rigby instead of the .375 H&H. For a two-gun safari, the 7mm RM and the .416 will take anything.

Have been using the 308 round for a long time now I have killed deer, coyotes, boar and any game that the north America has. From 50yrds out to 600yards. This round does get the fame like the the rest. It also nato round it would be easier to get if need.<!--mobile-->
I will stick with the following. 1. 45.70, 2. 44 Mag., 3. 30.06. If it don't begin with a 4, I don't much care for.

The 30-30 may not have much bark , but if used properly , it has bite . The 30-06 does cover more bases , but I kind of like light nimble lever actions . But if need be for All large and intermediate game , a good mauser action 375 can`t be beat . Bullet choice is very important , regardless of caliber .
You only need 2 cartridges: .223 and .308 [(]30/06 is the same[)]
.375 H&H? You were joking, weren't you?
Alberto & David, the .375 H&H when properly loaded, can take anything on earth. I'd not want to face a charging coastal grizzly with a .308. But hey, that's just me. I have one, and I use it.
I use a Remington 700 in 6.5x55 Swedish.shooting 140gr. Nosler Ballistic tips.Flat shooting,light recoil,folds them everytime.

Have the .30.30 and 308. Have shot both considerably and have come to the conclusion that I would take the. 30.30 any day of the week and 2x on Sunday. My last deer with it was 220 yards, and that with open sights. Definitely the rifle man and not the fancy stuff.<!--mobile-->
Can't believe you didn't include the .270 Winchester! ;[)]<!--mobile-->
I have four of the five in my safe [(]don't have a .375[)]. Regarding comments about where is the .308...it is offspring of the 30-06...a shorten version to go in a smaller magazine.

Where's the 8mm Mauser? I like this cartridge a lot, depending on how it's loaded. From 250 gr down to varmint size there is a lot of variety there. There isn't any 8mm/ .22 sabots though. I'm a semi-collector with rifles in probably at least 25 calibers from .22 to .68 two band Enfield and have hunted with most of them. Isn't the USA great!
Goes to show everyone has a good rounded opinion. My choice is 223, 308 and 7 mm mag
I love the 270.<!--mobile-->

Usually most gun writers quote ammunition sales when stating which cartridges are most popular. With hunting being on severe decline for many years due to the expense and lack of personal time most people today shoot military cartridges which rate high in ammunition sales. The .223, .308, 7.62x39 probably rate at the top in ammunition sales in both popularity and in volume of sales.
Hunting cartridges are a different story. Your omission of the .270 was quite a blunder for sure as it is often rated higher in ammo sales than the 7mm mag and comes close to sales of the 3006. And lets not forget the varmint hunters either. No mention made of the 22-250 either.
Few people use the .375 H&H because in North America its simply not needed. Few people can afford big bear hunting in Alaska and those that do go often use smaller calibers like the very popular .338 Winchester Magnum.
My 300 Win Mag with a Shepherd scope and my custom 22-250 shooting 70 gr. TSX-BT is all I need.

Don't overlook the up and coming 6.8 SPC II. GASP!!! A black-rifle cartridge on this list!?!?!? Write this article in 15 years and it may be on there... However I agree that the 30-06 is the best all around cartridge. The 6.8 SPC is the best for everything elk sized and smaller although moose and brown bear have been taken with it. There's my 2 pennies and I'm sticking to it!

The .308 can never equal the 30-06 ballistically...you can't get as much powder in the smaller case. And, beyond 300 yards the 30-06 has more energy than a .375 H&H. As far as accuracy is concerned, my 30-06 will shoot 0.7' 5-shot groups at 200 yards...guess what my favorite cartridge is... :[)]

30-30. Anything I am going to hunt, that round and my Marlin 336 will do the job. I used to have a Model 94, but an ex-wife disposed of it while I was overseas. Model 94's are now priced out of my range.
Wow a lot of people cant read. You guys complaining 'what about the 270' go back and reread the first section. Un-observant readers' comments aside, great article.
Why the 7MM? I've seen more critters wounded in AK with that cartridge than any other. The 7MM is to big for coyotes and too small for anything big <!--mobile-->

The .22-250 Ackley Improved, with the right bullet and shot placement, will suffice up white tail deer. I know a number of Iowa farmers who tell me they sit at the front door with the rifle resting on a chair. Mr. Antlers comes along and goes down with a brain shot. Legal? No. Dead? Very. The .300 Weatherby will, with the right bullet and shot placement, kill anything that walks the face of this earth. Those 2 cartridges are all you really need, and the W'by will do it all. So why do I have a .308, .30-06, an M4 [(]5.56[)], and a .45-70 with 500 grain Grizzly bullets for it? Damned if I know, but they sure are fun to shot. In the end, though, it'd be the 1917 Enfield .30-06 I'd keep. It is without a doubt the single most usefull and reliable cartridge ever invented. If an '06 won't do it, you've got the wrong ammunition in the right caliber.

This is really a Jim Zumbo list of favorites. With the popularity of semi automatics soring, all these are fudd chamberings. I submit the 762x51[[].308], as the best all around because it can be chambered in modern hunting guns. I the rest of the world, the 375 hh might be as you say, yet this is the usa and I don't know single soul that has one. So off the list it goes. Replaced by the 270 as the best all around fudd gun chambering. I own many 3006 rifles but the 270 has the edge. You may replace the thudy thudy with 762x39. The .223[[]556x45] is now legal in many states for deer and is the most popular varmit round. Even though I love the 22-250.

In 1900 there was a woman named Agnes Herbert and later in time a man named W.D.M. Bell. Both people found out after hunting more animals than could be hunted today in 10 lifetimes that it was bullet penetration and bullet placement that killed not bullet diameter.
A velocity of only 2,300 fps in the 6.5 Mannlicher cartridge with a long heavy 160 grain bullet was the only cartridge Mr. Bell used that would consistently shoot right through the head of an elephant. Agnes Herbert also found no difference in killing power between here .450 elephant rifle and the 6.5 Mannlicher cartridge. Both people shot all manner of big game with the cartridge and used full metal jacketed bullets.
A few years ago there was a TV special on culling an elephant herd. The shooters used the .308 with military 150 grain bullets that were full metal jacketed and all the elephants shot dropped like stones, no big bore elephant rifles were used or needed. Seeing is believing.

22-250 is a round that I will always have close at hand 270 would be next really like the range speed and how flat they shoot. But the only one if I could have only one would be the 300 weatherby mag superior knock down power with the heavier rounds and again flat and fast<!--mobile-->

Agree on the .30-06 & .30-30. Available in large quantities everywhere at reasonable prices. Wide range of bullet weights. .22 LR would have a place, if it were available. ' ******* horders' have made ruined that. Hope they all lose $ when suddenly the shelves are full.
Im partial to the 7.62x39 myself.<!--mobile-->
If I was limited to 1 gun in my valt it would be my model 70 280. Plenty of gun for North America. I'm not going to Africa.<!--mobile-->
I own .270 - 30-06 - 30-30 Have taken deer, elk, and antelope with all 3. also bagged a deer with .41 mag Ruger Blackhawk. My Favorite .270
I own one rifle, a 7.62x39 SKS. It does what I need it to do well. Down the road I would like a 30-30 and a .308 but I'm fine for now.
What's about the good old 8x57IS? :-[)]<!--mobile-->

I have shot all those rounds and my favorite cartridges are the 7mm and 300 RUM. Being from Alaska and having to make long shots sometimes those two calibers are flat shooting and hard hitting and distances greater than 500 meters. The 30-06 is a great round but the average bullet drop is over 30 inches at 500 yards compares to the 7mm, 21 inches, and 300 RUM, 16 inches. <!--mobile-->
I agree with other posters that these are Zumbofudd cartridges. Though I will still pull out a WCF 32SPL scoped rifle when feeling nostalgic, MSR's are the future and what should be focused on.

Pretty close to right on. I think I would like to see the addition of a hotshot .22, either .223 or 22-250, my personal favorite for smaller animals. But, what do you replace to make room for it? The list is pretty close to right on. I might think about replacing the 7 Mag due to it's similar ballistic performance to the 30-06
and it's rather hefty appetite for powder.<!--mobile-->

30 06 leads the way cause so many other hunters have the same bullets just in clase. 257 roberts is also in the cabinet and it goes for a walk every year to keep a 50 year promise. Also have 30/30 for those brushy areas of new england where scopes don't make sense<!--mobile-->
The 30-06 is great and so is the 308. Killed more deer with a 50 caliber black powder gun then anything. Early bird gets the worm<!--mobile-->

The 30-06, 7mm, and .300 mag are too similar. I'd pick one of them, or no more than two. For all that matter, the 30-30, isn't that different, although I'd concede it is different enough to merit consideration. There is no varmint cartridge here, no small big game round, like a 6mm or 6.5mm. This is hardly an 'all-around' list. It is a list of .30s and bigger bore round. My list would be .223, 6.5mm Swede, 30-06 [(]or 7mm mag[)] and .375, with one more of the reader's choice that could fit his favorite purpose - a .22 centerfire screamer for a varminter, or a medium bore for a bigger game hunter, for example.
I have 3 of those, 2 30-30 and 1 30-06, they are great guns and I wouldn't sell them for the world--It's worth mentioning that the 22wmr is a great gun also, you wouldn't believe the power!

I am a faithful to my 7mm I've hunted big game and varmits with it and have all game shot with it expire with 50-75 yards....it's a great flat shooting gun personally I think it should be at the top of the list<!--mobile-->
I shoot twenty eight different calibers. I like them all. Everybody has a favorite cartridge and an opinion. Luckily the choices are many. <!--mobile-->

I live my x-bolt 300wsm 150gr accu-bombs. My second choice for close up work is my old Marlin lever gun in .44mag with 240gr XTPs. Can't recall anything I've shot with either round ever getting up. I won't discredit any of the calibers listed because I've shot them all and have seen them all in action. In the end a well placed shot with the proper bullet will drop the target. <!--mobile-->
How ever said the 30-06 was wepon of spanish amarican war does not know how teddy was and the first center fire wepon after black powder was 30/40 krag not 06 it came after 30/40 krag<!--mobile-->

I have a 30-30 to hunt deer in Georgia. With trees and under growth, I do not see deer past about 75 yards. When I am out west, I have a 338. The shots are always much longer. I think it depends on where you hunt and every caliber has strengths and weaknesses.
agree with 30-06, but would add the 270 and 223. As for the 375, cannot agree when the topic is 'all around' - I don't see how big game hunting in Africa relates - keep it real.
The .375 is more of a specialist cartridge. Great for Africa but I would consider the .308 a much better candidate for an 'all around cartridge' list.

Ive used my H&K 91a .308 to hunt with for 20 years. Gun control. Means being able to hit your target. Weird hunting with an assault weapon but that's what im use to. And my 1911 on my side. Gd combo with a large Coke on the side<!--mobile-->

6.5X55 Swede is my goto meat gun. From antelope to elk I have never 'tracked' an animal more than a few yards, and by that, I mean to say I have never had to track anything I have shot with that cartridge period!<!--mobile-->

I have to say the 25/06 ought to be up there. Ive killed hogs out to 500 yards and 2 hogs with one shot at 90 yards with 117gr federals. It seems to be the best all around rifle to me. You've short and long range with almost no recoil.<!--mobile-->

I find it hard to believe the 8mm Mauser is not on anyone's radar on this comment thread. The 7mm Rem-Mag is a popular round, sure. But, with just a bit more pep, and a bigger round all-in-all, I say 8mm Mauser all the way. It is too often overlooked by hunters, and my sporterized K98 is one of the best deer rifles I have fired. Long range, and put down ability is better than most 7mmMags I've fired. The -06 however, is def a better all-around. And a .308 Win is the most developed round in the 20th/21st century for hunters and sport shooters alike. So, there's my rant. Thanks for reading y'all!

I agree with most of the comments. Especially those advocating the venerable .270
One has escaped everyone's comments and it is one of the very very best all around rounds, if not the best in my opinion
Roy's favorite...... WBY .257 mag<!--mobile-->
If I could only have one rifle, my choice would be to move to a different country!
I would also submit the.303 British, has taken more game around the world and was the model for our .30-06
The .270 didn't make the list and the .375 Holland & Holland Magnum did? Epic fail!
I shot more elk than you can imagine with the 270 W.<!--mobile-->

No doubt, the '06 is probably the most versatile and popular, but my favorite short range whitetail caliber is my trusted .35 Remington. It hits hard and is a bit forgiving and perfect for new or petite hunters.<!--mobile-->

Having been a reloader for over 30 years, I would also question the .375 in this list. I would also question the .300 and the 7mm. Not questioning at all their abilities, but you said an overall round? I would think the .270 would be the over all round. You can hunt everything from elk to squirrels with it given the right combination of powders and bullets.

Lots of criteria to use when making such choices, but the one calibre for the rifle you like the most, is the best. For me it's the .45/70 Govt. I reckon a lot of controversy would be solved, if we all used black powder firearms and the old rule of 'use enough gun' would be met, for about anything on the North American continent, with the good old .45-70. Modern arms it would have to be a 7mm Mag. As flat shooting as the .264 Win and hard hitting as an '.06, but I like cowboy era hardware the best.
I'm surprised the .270 didn't make the list also. That's what I use and most of my family <!--mobile-->
Even though I'm a 300 wim mag nut I'm surprised the 308 or the 25/06 didn't make the cut especially the 308<!--mobile-->
I have owned a Rem 700 7mm mag for 30 years. It is the most accurate round and dependable round I have ever used. Solid accuracy and hard hitting. It should top the list

No love for the .243? It is a very versatile bullet. You can go down to 50 or 55 grain for coyote, or up to 130 grain for deer. A great all around round for most North American game except bear or moose.<!--mobile-->

Here in SC where I live,I find the 308 and the 30-30 do very well. Most of the time I hunt underbrush and the edge of pasture land needless to say the 30-6 is more effective for a longer range shot,but if you're looking for the power pack punch go with the 300mag it 'will get the job done.'
I think everyone missed the point to 'all around' and for that the 50 bmg is definitely missing I can take anything from squirrels a truck with this thing

I've owned all the rifles on this list and all except the 375H&H [(]which I really don't hunt with[)] has been replaced by a .300 RUM. It replaced my previous favorite .300 Wby which was needed a new barrel. The 300 mags have way too many ballistic advantages over the 270, which it appears there is a lot of advocation for in the comments. The round that I'm really surprised was overlooked is the .243 WIN. That was the first centerfire round for all of my sons and in their hands, has taken everything from whitetail in KS to Roosevelt elk in the coast range of Oregon. One of my sons took a big horn sheep with his as well.

No .270!? I live in Alaska and have taken everything from grouse to grizzly bears with 150 grain factory loads. But by all means, let's go grouse hunting with a .30-30 or .375 Holland...I'll shoot, you go try and find the pieces.<!--mobile-->

.375 really?
No .270 on the list?
My pick for all around best is .243. It can be loaded for almost anything, from squirrels to elk!<!--mobile-->

Great article. I'm a .30-06 man myself, but I have to admit I've always wanted a .375 H&H Magnum. Not sure why... I know I'll never be able to hunt anything for which you would actually need such a round.
As much as I like the 300 I think the 375 should be taken out and the 284 win put in its place but that's just me <!--mobile-->

I have the .30-06, .7mm Rem. Mag. & .308, for my long range needs, [(]shy of the .50 cal. MA DUCE[)], I kinda use my .30-30, for anything, close up, with-in 100 yds. don't know why, but the .30-30, just doesn't seem to be to accurate, past that, maybe because it's a carbine[(]lever action?[)]. I use my AR-15's .223, only at the range, for now, the way things seem to be swaying, there intended uses, may materialize, soon, although, I have used them to hunt smaller game[(]varmints and predators[)] for OTHER Varmints, & predators, I use my hand guns. I AM, particular to my 1911 .45's, for an up close, intimate encounter. I also have the Henry big boy, in .45 long colt cal. so that when I carry my Blackhawks, I need but carry one cal. round. Usually when riding, but, I carry my bond arms derringer, .45/.410, loaded 410 snake slayer rounds, for snakes, and the such...

What about the 35 Whelan it can be Handle add
What about the 35 Whelan it will do just about anything the vernable 375 will do and is more appropriate in the Americas
<!--mobile-->

All the .375 H&H bashers don't seem to understand the wide range of applications of the cartridge. It does well with low loads and light bullets for medium game hunting, is a capable large game rifle, and with fmj an excellent African game rifle. As one of the most versatile cartirdges, it has more right to be here than any other on this list besides the 30-06.

I have to say my model III savage 25-06 will do just about anything I want it to I'm also shooting reloads which are leaving the barrel at a little over 3600 f.p.s. And have killed whitetail at a little over 600 yards with it<!--mobile-->
I strongly feel the 7x57 is a must for this list.

I've helped tons of people fill their tags in Wyoming and California, I don't agree with the list as the 30-30 and the .375 aren't that common. The .270 is huge and ballisticly a great all around rifle. Also, I see .243 caliber rifles used often on big game and small game. To me saying the .375 is one of the top 5 is like saying that a Barrett 50 cal is number 6... <!--mobile-->

The .375 H&H belongs because it's by far the most common [(]and many would say finest[)] big/dangerous game round in the world.
The lack of a varmint round is very questionable to me. So is the inclusion of the 7mm and even the 30-30.
I have a AR15 chambered for 300AAC Blackout it is as powerful as a 7.62 x 39mm and as good as a 30-30. It is also used with supersonic and subsonic loads. Great all around rifle.<!--mobile-->

I also have two of those...kind of. The .30-06 which I have hunted with for 45 years and a 25-35 [(]mentioned with the 30-30[)] that was handed down to me from my grandfather. The 25-35 and 30-30 are both good brush guns. I have done some pretty long and close range shooting with the 30-06...its hard to beat as an all around cartridge. I would agree that the .270 should have made the list.
Where is the Midwest trusted .243 I've taken every type of critter that runs thru ND with this round<!--mobile-->
I would put 308 up there in top 3. most people will never have a need for a .375 H&H

I've lived and hunted in Montana all my life [(]55 years[)] and own many hunting rifles , but every time I go out serious elk hunting its always the .270 Win that comes along.I have shot many elk, bear, deer, moose with it and it never fails to impress me. It definitely should be in the top 5!<!--mobile-->

The .303 British as the 'model' for the .30-06??? Whoever made this comment is phenomenally ignorant about the history of firearms. If anything could be said to be the 'model' for the .30-06 it would be the 8x57 Mauser.
The .30-6 is far and away the most useful, flexible, and versatile caliber in the list. I have used it on many deer and big African antelope, and there's nothing in North America it will not handle cleanly.
The .270 is fine for lightly built animals and for hunting open terrain. Great round for sheep and even whitetails. But it is over-rated, and nowhere near so versatile as the .30-06. A very poor choice for the 'one rifle' man, Jack O'Connor's opinion to the contrary notwithstanding. I have seen more African game lost with a .270 than any other caliber, usually by American hunters who think it's some sort of powerhouse, which it isn't. The .30-06 outclasses it in all respects except flat trajectory, which isn't that important.
The .30-06 is immensely popular in Africa, as is the .375 H&H, another grand 'all around' rifle. Though little used here, it has been used successfully on everything from duiker to elephant and if there is a single most useful African caliber [(]as the .30-06 is the single most useful American one[)] it's the .375.

I only use three center-fire calibers for game. .223, .308, 30-06. If it's too small for the 223, use a .22; if it's too big for a 30-06 it's probably armored and will shoot back. Anything in between use the .308. Easy.<!--mobile-->
What about 223/556 308/7.62nato there amazing all around rounds<!--mobile-->
Have owned a 270 for 40 plus years and over all tough to beat. Also have a 44mag and a 5.65 one for fun and the other for smaller game. All three have given me a lot of pleasure
Hunted for 35 years with a 308. Have never been disappointed. 10 yard shots to 400 yards. Amazing caliber. <!--mobile-->

While I'm an owner/builder of 'MSRs', use them 'professionally', and do hunt them; MSRs will never have the feel or nostalgia or 'hunt' as well, for those of us weaned on walnut and blue and bolts and levers. I could cover all of those cartridges [(]and do[)], with a 7x57 & .358W...I have some listed, and the '06 and 30-30 are great....but having lots of stuff available and each his own druthers is what spins the gun world. <!--mobile-->

I own two 3006s, a 270, a 223 but my go to is a browning 300w. I've hunted all my life [(]I'm 71[)] but I don't like to kill things and detest dealing with cripples. I do love wild meat. The 300w with a 150g power point seldom leave a deer alive. After dozens of kills, I have yet to have a slug go all the way through a deer. The slug usually looks like a fifty cent coin. All the energy is spent on the target. My 300 is a bit heavy but with a gold ring scope is deadly up to 300yds [(] don't take longer shots for fear of cripples[)] My father taught me, if you kill it eat it. Sense, I don't care to eat an elephant or bear, I really don't even think about a 375 0r even a 380. A 3006 is deadly accurate and consistent as has been proven at the thousand yards completions for many years, but will go through a deer almost every time. the slug and what you are using the rifle for counts.
People, the 30-30 has taken more deer then any other caliber. I shoot a .270 winchester. Shoots flater than the 30-06
I prefer the 6.8mm 110 gran

Veery surprised the lowly .22 did not make it! I learned to shoot using one and took more game [(]small that is[)] to fill the pot year round than my 30-30 and 30-06 combined. All cartridges mentioned in the article I have shot and in my humble opinion, the 30-06 [(]basic cartridge for the .270, .25-06, 35 whelan, etc,[)] is hands down the most versatile and can be loaded with anything from a 85 grain varmint bullet up to a 220 grain moose banger! Plenty enough for anything that walks, slithers, crawls or runs in the lower 48!
270 and 308 have killed way more game than a 375.....270 is actually a more powerful cartridge after 200 yds than the 30-06. crazy article that was a waste of time
I would chose the 8mm Mauser or 7.62X54R. Both are great weapons, accurate and can handle long or short range easy. I would chose the mauser first just for for the smoother action.

The .270 and .280 are both in the third paragraph. As a lifetime member of the NRA, l believe the purpose of these essays are to stimulate conversation among rifle shooters. As for myself, I believe shot placement and a clean kill are paramount to bullet diameter. However, for the last 22 years my BAR Safari II in .300 Win Mag with 150, 180 and 220 grain bullets have never failed me. Thank you Mr. Campbell for stimulating the conversation.
I disagree with the 300 mag an 375. The 243 or 6mm very vers. range an affectiveness very good along with accurate an recoil good. 270 also good. and lets not forget the 223 <!--mobile-->

Semi-strange list for a top 5 'all-around' cartridge in my opinion. My top 5.
1. .308 2. .30-06 3. .30-30 4. .270 5. .45-70
I love the .243<!--mobile-->
30-06/30-30/270/.375/ maybe 8mm mauser, although I might be prone to stick 45-70 in there,

I think people are missing the point as this is a list of an all rounder! As in u have only one gun which to shoot small to large game and the .223 or .22lr would not compete also the .270 win would not stand against very large game. <!--mobile-->

I agree that the 30-06 & 30-30 should be there.. Not crazy about the other 3. Where is the 45-70 Gov? It had been around since the frontier days and was originally loaded with Blackpowder.. It has killed a lot of big game and is the preferred guide gun in the Northwest.. It also defended a lot of wagon trains headed west..<!--mobile-->

I agree with the selection you made with the mild exception of the 30-30. I suggest you could have said that two cartridges, the 30-06 and the 375 H&H could handle any rifle hunting you might care to do, anywhere in the world.
For many reasons the one rifle limit would require a .308 Win. Almost 30/06 performance, lots of available brass, lots of available ammo, etc.<!--mobile-->

I think you should see what are the most sold cartridges and you will probably come up with 30-06, 308. and 30-30 for big game. The rest may be fine cartridges but are not used near as much by the average hunter. I own all three and would take my 308 first.
I like my 38-55.<!--mobile-->
what about the .338 lapua?
good article.
30:06 has always been my favorite cartridge. It can take down any big game in North America and it is available in several bullet weights.
308, 243? Come on, do these people even know what they are talking about?
The Winchester 30-30 has probably killed more Deer in the south, than any other cartridge combined!!
What about 338 mag <!--mobile-->
Hard to beat the .30-'06 as #1. I'd add the .308 to the list and agree with the .375 H & H selection. I'd have to include two venerable military calibers, too: .303 British and 6.5 Swede
Darren pretty well nailed it: . 1. .308 2. .30-06 3. .30-30 4. .270 5. .45-70 Sure, the magnums have gained in popularity recently, but no way should they even make this list.

.220 Swift and .284 Win.
Unpopular choices I know. But I've have lots of good look with both
I have the Winchester model 70 in 30-06 and a old Winchester model 94 in 30-30. All I have ever used or needed and taken all the game I ever needed.

I find that most hunters are way too over gunned. Using cannons to hunt deer and other medium size game. I believe that the 30-06 is the most versitile cal. for all North American hunting but I choose the .308 and have had success with deer, black bear and elk. I only pull the trigger when I know that I will make a killing shot. I am old now and prefer less recoil and am looking for a .257 Roberts and a .250 Savage. By the way I have killed many deer with a .22 and they went right down but I don't reccommend it for hunting as most hunters don't make killing shots and therefore want to hunt with cannons. Now if I were hunting dangerous game I would probably use the .338.

So many complaints about the 375H&H, but the article said all around cartridges, not all around for the USA or North America. In Africa [(]yes I've been there[)] it's the best all around used it from Impala [(]smaller than a whitetail[)] to a hippo.<!--mobile-->
250-3000 Savage is great but hard to find.<!--mobile-->
I like my 300 RUM 150/180/220 gr good all around big game ammo
Love my 7 rem mag. Dropped everything from prairie dogs up to and including north American bison. I call it the zinger :[)] lol<!--mobile-->
I use three rifles for everything in tha USA, for longrange .25-06, for close range [(]brush Gun and dangerous game[)] .44 mag and for small game .22lr
.308 [(]7.62 x 51[)] still king for sniping and for normal hunting ranges for most game...100-300 yards

I see the 223/5.56 mentioned as an all around? Why? Have you ever hunted for anything larger than a dog with one? I have.. A Deer to be exact was off on my placement by not even an inch and I hit the shoulder didn't penetrate just split the skin and the deer lived seen it the next year.. And forget an elk or moose with a 223.. They were developed and made for light shines animals and human like flesh.. Very thin and weak.. <!--mobile-->

I have a custom .375 H & H that I am thinking about selling. Great gun and perfect for when I was hunting in Alaska! But I prefer my .270 now as I do not expect to be facing a grizzly anytime in the future! Anyone interested? <!--mobile-->

I have read all the articles on it and ran all the numbers several times using varying data and I am about two weeks out from completing what I would say is my perfect all around rifle, the 338 federal. Not popular here in the states I know but sounded peefect for me.<!--mobile-->
.308 will ALWAYS be the rifle of choice by our military . they dont mention the .308 because it's hard enough right now to buy ammo for it.. nice pop for the other calipers though!!! [=][)]

30-06 is great no doubt, I own two! However for getting the job done and stretching shots out further I prefer my 7mm rem mag. I do find it funny that the 6.5x55 Swedish get no mention. It's outstanding as well. <!--mobile-->
Finally a clear and well review of rifle calipers. Can you add a write up for pistols and revolvers ?<!--mobile-->

I harvested a deer with my Dad's 30-30 Winchester 94 with open sights at 224 yards with one shot when I was in highschool. I did not know the distance for several years until I purchased a range finder. I'd say it was my proudest moment in hunting. <!--mobile-->
Uh, I didn't see anything about a 270. I love my 270 and when its hunting season I don't grab anything else. When the 270 talks everyone listens.<!--mobile-->
I still use my 30-40 Krag for deer. Bought it in 1965 for 15 dollars. model 1898 SPRINGFIELD ARMORY

I don't have a problem with any caliber mentioned but there is something terribly wrong with any list that puts the 375 H&H and the 30 30 WCF in the same list. Come on, all of these cartridges are useful bu the 375 nor the 30 30 are 'all around' cartridges, they are just about on the opposite ends of the spectrum.

If I was limited to just one caliber it would be a 30-06. It will take any North American game and you have a variety of bullets available for any hunt plus if things go bad and you need ammo this round will be more available than the less popular rounds.

.223 for varmints, rabbits, squirrels [(]you 'bark' them[)]. .243 for white tail deer, antelope, goats, small pigs. .270 for mule deer, sheep, large pigs. .300 H&H for bear, moose. Oh, and a .22 rimfire for tin cans! My idea of a near-perfect battery. I also have .30-06, .257 Roberts, and other odds and ends. That is the great thing about the USA, you can have your gun, and shoot it too.

I've recently found another cartrige that I am greatly empressed with. I have two Lee-Enfield 303s that find very accurate with reloads I make. The 150 grain bullet leaves the barrle at over 2800 feet per second and does a 4 inch group at 200 yards. I'm impressed.

A bullet is only as good as the shooter. If you are a poor shot use bigger bullets. I one shot kill deer with .223, 243 and 308, consistantly. Some may need a rocket launcher. I like undamaged meat personally.

I'm surprised there is so little mention of the .243. It's certainly not a one rifle solution. But most of us are primarily deer hunters. I'm no expert but I've killed 3 dozen deer with a .243 and all but 2 have fallen over dead with the first shot. The Nosler partition bullet never exits the deer. All of the energy stays in the animal. The Browning BLR is the best deer rifle ever in my opinion. Although, I've been using a Ruger #1 .243 the past 12 years because 1 shot is all I ever need.
The 30 06 is without question the best 1 rifle option for most of us in my opinion.

item.title: Fifth-Place Finish for Bass Pro Shops/NRA Museum Chevy at Daytona
item.creator: Justin_McDaniel
item.content_encoded: Circumstances were in Austin Dillon's favor last Sunday as he crossed the finish line in fifth place at Daytona, driving the iconic No. 3 Chevrolet made famous by the late Dale Earnhardt. The NASCAR rookie delivered one of his best performances in his short career with the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series. Carrying a special NRA Museum paint scheme donated by primary sponsor Bass Pro Shops, Dillon earned a career-best fifth-place finish in Sunday's rain-shortened Coke Zero 400 at Daytona International Speedway. The race, won by NASCAR journeyman Aric Almirola, was originally scheduled to be run on Saturday evening but was moved to Sunday morning due to rain. Dillon escaped a pair of huge, multi-car crashes and was in the right place at the right time when yet more rain showers forced NASCAR to abbreviate the race after 112 of the scheduled 160 laps. "It was a great day for the No. 3 Bass Pro Shops/NRA Museum team," Dillon said. "There were a few accidents on the track that we got through and I'm still scratching my head. I'll have some stories to tell my kids one day, that's for sure. There were cars in the air right in front of me." The top-five finish provided an exclamation point to Dillon's impressive 2014 showing at Daytona, where he placed ninth in the season-opening Daytona 500 in February after winning the pole position for "The Great American Race." Turning in his two best performances of the year at Daytona is only fitting considering that this season Dillon is driving the No. 3 Chevrolet made famous by the late Dale Earnhardt. The seven-time series champion was a master at navigating the superspeedway's 2.5-mile, high-banked circuit, visiting victory lane at Daytona a record 34 times during his illustrious career. Earnhardt's signature No. 3 had been unofficially retired from Sprint Cup Series competition since his death in a last-lap crash in the 2001 Daytona 500. Earnhardt's longtime car owner, Richard Childress, an NRA Board member, also happens to be Dillon's grandfather, and he brought the No. 3 back to the track for his grandson's rookie Sprint Cup season. With both Childress and Dillon being hunters and staunch NRA supporters, the backdrop of Independence Day weekend provided a perfect opportunity for Bass Pro Shops to highlight the new NRA National Sporting Arms Museum. A joint effort between NRA and Bass Pro, the museum is located inside the outdoor retail giant's flagship store in Springfield, Mo., and traces America's rich hunting heritage through a collection of more than 1,000 historically-significant firearms. Open daily from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m., the NRA National Sporting Arms Museum is located at 1935 S. Campbell Ave. in Springfield, Mo., and admission is free. Since opening last August, the museum has hosted some 300,000 visitors, and thanks to Bass Pro Shops' generosity and Dillon's strong showing in Daytona, many more are certain to follow.
item.excerpt_encoded: Austin Dillon delivered an impressive career-best showing in Sunday's Coke Zero 400 at Daytona International Speedway.
item.category: nra museum chevy finishes fifth at daytona

item.title: Snap Shots Week 8: Where the Buffalo [Don’t] Roam … and Unclaimed Bacon
item.creator: keefe
item.content_encoded: Congratulations to our winner for “Snap Shots Week 7: When Taxidermy Attacks II: ... and a Cool Bipod.” Ed Hosey, who responded to this post on our website takes this week’s laurels for the following: “[T]old my husband we were getting a cat ... he seemed reluctant at first ... but I think they finally have bonded ... .” Ed, your bipod will be sent when we find someone who knows how to operate the postage machine. When you have magazines dating back to 1885, you end up flipping through pages and chuckling at times over what you find. Although American Rifleman is the world’s oldest and largest firearms authority, it doesn’t mean we can’t have a little fun. And we’re willing to share that fun with our readers. Thus continues the American Rifleman’s weekly photo caption contest. Now, on to Week 8 and another historical gem. “Don’t move. He can’t see us if we don’t move” or “You didn’t come out here for the hunting, did you?” Yes, back before there were cartridge guns, hunters had to do it the old-fashioned way with the muzzleloading longrifle. Why he is reloading and why the buffalo are not roaming, we have no idea. It might be Pennsylvania, as everyone knows Pennsylvania is flintlock only. Okay, it’s probably not Pennsylvania. You might want to pick up a flint though, buddy. They work better that way. This week’s prize is back by popular demand. Or rather unpopular demand. It’s a can of CMMG Tactical Bacon that remains unclaimed-and unopened. It is the Susan Lucci of our prize packs. For a full description of our dissed prize offering, read below. Keep it clean. Bloomberg probably pays an intern minimum wage to read this blog. Entries will be subjectively judged by staff editors between takes of the TV show, testing guns and making authors seem literate. The winner we deem worthy will be printed here. All judgments final. No returns. Winner will receive a random item from a box under Mark Keefe's desk the manufacturer did not want back, yet was marginally valuable enough to not throw away. This week’s reprised special guest judge is American Hunter's own Shawn Skipper, who contributed the most satisfying prize to date. As if just being bacon were not enough-Mmm, bacon-we have an actual can of CMMG’s Tactical Bacon. That’s right, 9 ozs. of bacon, perhaps combat-ready bacon, delivered to your door if you have the best caption for this week’s photo. The instruction on the can are very clear “Open can” followed by step two, which is “receive bacon.” Actually we have no idea what is actually in this can. It is probably bacon, but it could be cling peaches from the Eisenhower Administration. We don’t really know.
